commit_message:
Move test utility to common location

Several of the test clases for testing the service provider API were
duplicating a method to build a request body. Instead of duplicating
a common and useful utility, we can move it to a generic place and
share it.

This commit creates a new method in keystone.tests.unit.core for
building service provider entities to be used in API and backend
tests. A subsequent patch will rely on this for testing policy
protection of the service provider API.

Change-Id: I78e697f9f5fb975b4694ab1a61f608a6dce0fd3b

commit_message:
Fix the partial missing metrics in Create Alarm Definition flow

- The UI will call the monasca-api more than once to get all
metrics when the limit of API is exceeded.
- Added compatibility to cassandra and influxdb

Change-Id: I15c53c05517a6f8eb0fc29f3adc3667485ee6772
Story: 2004430
Task: 28091

commit_message:
Allow configure java params for ODL karaf

Allow configure memory limits as variables in ODL karaf
java instance.
Allows us to define smaller memory settings for CI
and bigger for prod environments.

Change-Id: I8cafaa543ad09572bdbb6af1bbbd65f55fe42f8c

[{'created': '2016-01-10 07:52:06.000000000', 'message': 'Delete python bytecode before every test run

Because python creates pyc|pyo files and __pycache__
directories during tox runs, certain changes in the tree,
like deletes of files, or switching branches, can create
spurious errors.

The target bytecodes for deletion are in normal directories,
but not in dot started directory.

Change-Id: I5b94118eba45c10c13d77732a0ace64c54e97b05
'}]
commit_message:
Delete python bytecode before every test run

Because python creates pyc|pyo files and __pycache__
directories during tox runs, certain changes in the tree,
like deletes of files, or switching branches, can create
spurious errors.

The target bytecodes for deletion are in normal directories,
but not in dot started directory.

Change-Id: I5b94118eba45c10c13d77732a0ace64c54e97b05

commit_message:
Show error message from body where no error key in body

When i use CLI with `cloudkitty hashmap-mapping-create -s service_id
-c cost -v value -t rate -g group_id -p project_id`, the cloudkitty
return body with `{u'debuginfo': None, u'faultcode': u'Client',
u'faultstring': u"You can't specify a value and a service_id."}`,
and the client can't show the error message of faultstring.

This patch just fixes this.

Change-Id: Idbf554ba30dda1197e032c9f925dbf06983d8897

commit_message:
Add region name when doing authentication

In multi region situation, the client always choices the default
region when no region name apply.

Change-Id: I30182d92dfaa5f953ba1d5362f2893f65c06613a

commit_message:
Fixed wrap from taking negative values

Now for wrap input it will take only postive integers as an input and
if any negative numbers are give it will give output as "Wrap argument
should be a positive integer".

Change-Id: Ia69ae245f07e46324b74e2be19fa0caff735edf8

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-03-21 06:31:42.000000000', 'message': 'Remove log translations

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.

See:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-i18n/2016-November/002574.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113365.html

Change-Id: I5b7d1d58a8b4ea5ddf5537d684b3c5c0e0e3fdc6
'}, {'created': '2017-07-05 07:35:12.000000000', 'message': 'Remove log translations

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.

See:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/446762/
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-i18n/2016-November/002574.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113365.html

Change-Id: I5b7d1d58a8b4ea5ddf5537d684b3c5c0e0e3fdc6
'}]
commit_message:
Remove log translations

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.

See:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/446762/
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-i18n/2016-November/002574.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113365.html

Change-Id: I5b7d1d58a8b4ea5ddf5537d684b3c5c0e0e3fdc6

commit_message:
Fix the partial missing metrics in Create Alarm Definition flow

- The UI will call the monasca-api more than once to get all
metrics when the limit of API is exceeded.
- Added compatibility to cassandra and influxdb

Change-Id: I15c53c05517a6f8eb0fc29f3adc3667485ee6772
Story: 2004430
Task: 28091

commit_message:
Fix the partial missing metrics in Create Alarm Definition flow

- The UI will call the monasca-api more than once to get all
metrics when the limit of API is exceeded.
- Added compatibility to cassandra and influxdb

Change-Id: I15c53c05517a6f8eb0fc29f3adc3667485ee6772
Story: 2004430
Task: 28091

commit_message:
Fix the partial missing metrics in Create Alarm Definition flow

- The UI will call the monasca-api more than once to get all
metrics when the limit of API is exceeded.
- Added compatibility to cassandra and influxdb

Change-Id: I15c53c05517a6f8eb0fc29f3adc3667485ee6772
Story: 2004430
Task: 28091

commit_message:
Updating "Create an Encrypted Volume Type" Picture

With reference to I038918e4beef2ea4d346127713855e0421e8b721.
The description for "Key Size" field is changed.
So picture for the same also need to be updated.
This patch updates the picture in the doc.

Change-Id: Idfed41249cd6e74ff0ad209798dfc5f921552ed9
Related-Bug: #1780457

commit_message:
Get centralized FIP only on router's snat host

It may happen that L3 agent works in dvr_snat mode but
it handles some router as "normal" dvr router because
snat for this router is handled on other node.
In such case we shouldn't try to get floating IPs cidrs
from snat namespace as it doesn't exists on host.

Change-Id: Ib27dc223fcca56030ebb528625cc927fc60553e1
Related-Bug: #1717302

commit_message:
Fix _get_config_generator_config_definition() typo

Argument is config_file, but conf is used in method, just
change definition.  Necessary if using python3.

Change-Id: I6d92b3718810589c35974571278574d0906fce36

commit_message:
ceph-base/dind: switch to btrfs-progs package

Starting with 4.4.1 release btrfs-tools were renamed to btrfs-progs so
*-tools package became transitional one.

Next stable Debian release will not have 'btrfs-tools' package at all.

Change-Id: I188eaad233c1dbdbfd1c115e02b0e1c66e307c20

[{'account_id': 28373, 'date': '2018-09-05 09:34:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-09-07 23:56:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(10 comments)

Based on my first reading of this spec, I think the first step would be to agree on nomenclature. What is a provider network? What is a managed provider network? Also we need to make sure we are aware of relevant currently existing extensions in the Neutron API. Please see my in-line comments'}, {'account_id': 4694, 'date': '2018-09-08 21:23:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Let's make sure we all start from the same definition: in Neutron, provider networks are networks created by the OpenStack administrator that map directly to an existing physical network in the data center. To be able to map the provider network to an existing physical network, the administrator uses the network attributes defined in this extension: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/provider_net.py. If the provider network maps to more that one segment in the physical infrastructure, then the attributes in the aforementioned extension can be combined in a list per this extension: https://github.com/openstack/neutron-lib/blob/master/neutron_lib/api/definitions/multiprovidernet.py.

Here's a good blog entry that contrasts provider networks with tenant and external networks: https://assafmuller.com/2018/07/23/tenant-provider-and-external-neutron-networks/

This is also a good video that covers concepts related to provider networks: https://www.openstack.org/videos/austin-2016/mapping-real-networks-to-physical-networks-segments-and-logical-networks-in-neutron"}, {'account_id': 17120, 'date': '2018-09-10 00:38:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-05 09:34:39.000000000', 'message': 'Provider Network Management

Provider networks are currently administered directly within ML2
configuration files [1] and therefore must be managed as part of the
host deployment and management.

This spec proposes an extension to make provider networks a first-class
citizen of Neutron by introducing an extension which exposes provider
network management via the Neutron API.

[1] /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini

Co-Authored-By: Matt Peters <matt.peters@windriver.com>

Implements: blueprint provider-network-management
Change-Id: I2e586bb6d51d32c0ac2a28b2429512cea036f363
'}, {'created': '2018-10-15 01:25:52.000000000', 'message': 'Network Segment Range Management

Currently, network segment ranges are configured as an entry in ML2
config file [1]_ that is statically defined for tenant network
allocation and therefore must be managed as part of the host deployment
and management. When a normal tenant user creates a network, Neutron
assigns the next free segmentation ID (VLAN ID, VNI etc.) from the
configured segment ranges; only anadministrator can assign a specific
segment ID via the provider extension.

This spec introduces an extension which exposes the segment range
management to be administered via the neutron API. In addition, it
introduces the ability for the administrator to control the segment
ranges globally or on a per-tenant basis.

[1] /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini

Co-Authored-By: Matt Peters <matt.peters@windriver.com>

Implements: blueprint network-segment-range-management
Change-Id: I2e586bb6d51d32c0ac2a28b2429512cea036f363

commit_message:
Network Segment Range Management

Currently, network segment ranges are configured as an entry in ML2
config file [1]_ that is statically defined for tenant network
allocation and therefore must be managed as part of the host deployment
and management. When a normal tenant user creates a network, Neutron
assigns the next free segmentation ID (VLAN ID, VNI etc.) from the
configured segment ranges; only an administrator can assign a specific
segment ID via the provider extension.

This spec introduces an extension which exposes the segment range
management to be administered via the Neutron API. In addition, it
introduces the ability for the administrator to control the segment
ranges globally or on a per-tenant basis.

[1] /etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini

Co-Authored-By: Matt Peters <matt.peters@windriver.com>

Implements: blueprint network-segment-range-management
Change-Id: I2e586bb6d51d32c0ac2a28b2429512cea036f363

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-22 08:47:12.000000000', 'message': 'Updated the take_actions for unified limits

When user passes --region None, the find_resource
of osc_lib calls get() of region. The get API of
region ignores the name param returning all the
regions in result. As the find_resource checks
many cases against the result returned by get API.
The output comes greater than 1, thus returning
"More than one region ID exist" which is incorrect.
However in case of region which cannot be filtered
by name we do not require to check these many cases.

The solution is to directly call the get method of
APIs and returning No resource name exist with the
xyz" on passing invaid parameter. And returning all
in case of None.

Thus created a new function get_resource which can
be used in future too by these types of API's.

Change-Id: Ib3f881d34a82af97199ce51bfbefc6f3f08599f1
Closes-bug: #1799513
'}, {'created': '2018-10-22 08:50:32.000000000', 'message': 'Updated the take_actions for unified limits

of osc_lib calls get() of region. The get API of
region ignores the name param returning all the
regions in result. As the find_resource checks
many cases against the result returned by get API.
The output comes greater than 1, thus returning
"More than one region ID exist" which is incorrect.
However in case of region which cannot be filtered
by name we do not require to check these many cases.

The solution is to directly call the get method of
APIs and returning No resource name exist with the
xyz" on passing invaid parameter. And returning all
in case of None.

Thus created a new function get_resource which can
be used in future too by these types of API's.

Change-Id: Ib3f881d34a82af97199ce51bfbefc6f3f08599f1
Closes-bug: #1799153
'}]
commit_message:
Updated the take_actions for unified limits

When user passes --region None, the find_resource
of osc_lib calls get() of region. The get API of
region ignores the name param returning all the
regions in result. As the find_resource checks
many cases against the result returned by get API.
The output comes greater than 1, thus returning
"More than one region ID exist" which is incorrect.
However in case of region which cannot be filtered
by name we do not require to check these many cases.

The solution is to directly call the get method of
APIs and returning No resource name exist with the
xyz" on passing invaid parameter. And returning all
in case of None.

Thus created a new function get_resource which can
be used in future too by these types of API's.

Change-Id: Ib3f881d34a82af97199ce51bfbefc6f3f08599f1
Closes-bug: #1799153

commit_message:
WIP  - Api performance enhancements

 - Topology code refactored to be more efficient
 - Backend APIs returning large data sets compress the response
 - Garbage Collector configured to collect when there are few
   collectable objects, rather then wait till there are many.
 - Garbage Collector called after every API call.

Change-Id: Ieda233932aff7e6621845544d94f73960ece834c

asdd

Change-Id: I274d3ed5ee47e6daaa48b518b77ff68e92002111

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-21 21:02:52.000000000', 'message': 'Specify python interpreter for undercloud

We always gather facts for the undercloud and which should match the
python interpreter that the inventory code was generated with.  This is
overridable with the --deploy-python-interpreter.

There is a single case where these might be mismatched from the
overcloud if a user is running python2.7 mistral containers on a python3
undercloud and uses config-download to deploy against python2.7
hosts. But I beleive this is not going to be a supported use case so we
should be able to default to the python version used to generate the
inventory file or use a specified value from the command line.

Change-Id: I877cf123d3ef4df045c95f8484e0b5f1ae66a8ba

commit_message:
Specify python interpreter for undercloud

We always gather facts for the undercloud and which should match the
python interpreter that the inventory code was generated with.  This is
overridable with the --deploy-python-interpreter.

There is a single case where these might be mismatched from the
overcloud if a user is running python2.7 mistral containers on a python3
undercloud and uses config-download to deploy against python2.7
hosts. But I beleive this is not going to be a supported use case so we
should be able to default to the python version used to generate the
inventory file or use a specified value from the command line.

Change-Id: I877cf123d3ef4df045c95f8484e0b5f1ae66a8ba
Related-Blueprint: python3-support

If the tempdir doesn't exist, we can get a cryptic error message when
using the bulk_symlink function. This change checks that the temp dir we

Closes-Bug: #1804527

commit_message:
Improve bulk symlink error handling

If the tempdir doesn't exist, we can get a cryptic error message when
using the bulk_symlink function. This change checks that the temp dir we
are to use exists prior to consuming it and throws a message indicating
the folder doesn't exist.

Change-Id: I3a4bf279d6d1c2c35c000e7b38b147a026cfcfb4
Closes-Bug: #1804527

commit_message:
Deprecate pki related options

check_revocations_for_cached and hash_algorithms are deprecated for
removel because of PKI token format is no longer supported.
Update warning message and add a release note.

Change-Id: Ib5dc556c9e39ff80161cfa35ce176a18b9ea6074
Closes-Bug: #1804562
Closes-Bug: #1804720

commit_message:
Remove pki related options

check_revocations_for_cached and hash_algorithms are deprecated for
removel because of PKI token format is no longer supported. We can
remove them.

Change-Id: Ieaf6176f0308bbf051e7b4dcd7e9fea793c5bc36
Closes-Bug: #1804562
Closes-Bug: #1804720

commit_message:
Add chaging secret key for external KMS section

This patch updates the overview_encryption page to add a
`Changing the encryption root secret of external KMS's` section
to point out the slight difference in naming. I.E:

  key_id_<secret_id> vs. encryption_root_secret_<secret_id>

This patch refers to both multikey support in the KMIP and KMS
key masters, so really should land after both of them.

Related-Change-Id: Ie52508e47d15ec5c4e96902d3c9f5f282d275683
Related-Change-Id: I4f485dcb31e5bea511c4e539c54681091fc5bb1c
Change-Id: Ie4cd8ae038501c8abc43d09cf0b207ca375a4366

commit_message:
Multi-key KMS keymaster

Now that the trivial keymaster supports multiple keys, let's not
forget about the KMS/Barbican keymaster. Additional keys are
configured as:

    key_id_<secret_id> = <KMS unique identifier>

As with the trivial keymaster, the key to use for PUTs and POSTs is
specified with:

    active_root_secret_id = <secret_id>

Change-Id: I4f485dcb31e5bea511c4e539c54681091fc5bb1c

commit_message:
Fix unit tests for elements

It looks like we dropped running these probably when we moved the
elements around.  For testtools to find the test scripts we need to
add the __init__.py files to make the directories look like modules.
Also prevent copying any .pyc or cache files in as hooks.

Change-Id: I66d5f6ee62cc4d9ee14c64e819b4db57d035d09f

commit_message:
Re-introduce gate_hook.sh in zunclient

The script gate_hook.sh was removed at Zun side [1] as part of
the effort for migrating to zuul v3 native job. However, zunclient
still need this script and the removal causes the failure of the
CI. This patch re-introduce the script at zunclient as a temporary
fix. The long-term fix is to migrate the job to zuul v3 native
as well.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/512209/

Change-Id: I93a4ec8804e74e17c478f2ee2ecf9b3402fcbd3f

messages: [{'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-11-28 03:06:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-11-28 15:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/queens as commit 216ba98b4e285c3d23ab68a876afb38b3cc2482e'}, {'account_id': 21428, 'date': '2018-11-29 02:11:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-28 03:06:10.000000000', 'message': 'Set HTTP header "Origin" when using websocket

This is because if this header is missing, the websocket client
will populate this header as "http://...", which is incorrect
if we are using secure connection (in which this header should
be "https://...").

Change-Id: I441946dc168db645744da093e215f65fa1ca3637
Related-Bug: #1762511
(cherry picked from commit 67660449617b2a884735f000f922faafe69659b0)
'}]
commit_message:
Set HTTP header "Origin" when using websocket

This is because if this header is missing, the websocket client
will populate this header as "http://...", which is incorrect
if we are using secure connection (in which this header should
be "https://...").

Change-Id: I441946dc168db645744da093e215f65fa1ca3637
Related-Bug: #1762511
(cherry picked from commit 67660449617b2a884735f000f922faafe69659b0)

commit_message:
Spec for volume-backed flavors

Proposes a discoverable way for admins to define flavors as being
backed by persistent storage and simplify the user experience for
creating a volume-backed instance.

APIImpact

Spec for blueprint volume-backed-flavors

commit_message:
Add failure domains, and device classes for custom CRUSH rules

Largely inspired and taken from Kranthi's PS.

 - Add support for creating custom CRUSH rules based off of failure
domains and device classes (ssd & hdd)
- Basic logic around the PG calculator to autodetect the number of
OSDs globally and per device class (required when using custom crush
rules that specify device classes).

Change-Id: I13a6f5eb21494746c2b77e340e8d0dcb0d81a591

commit_message:
Bump Ansible to 2.6.x

Bump the maximum supported version of Ansible to 2.6.x for both Kayobe
and Kolla Ansible.

Change-Id: Ia8691d127bb6ce57dcd6fdac25f0357844f5cbaa
Story: 2004287
Task: 27839

Someone pulled this down and was testing it today and noted that nova hypervisor-stats still shows local_gb_used as 1 for a volume-backed root_gb=1 instance, and I figured out that's due to this code in the RT:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/eb4f65a7951e921b1cd8d05713e144e72f2f254f/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L1455

That's now bfv-aware unlike the scheduler now and this other code we had when ocata computes would report allocations:

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/eb4f65a7951e921b1cd8d05713e144e72f2f254f/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L170

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/eb4f65a7951e921b1cd8d05713e144e72f2f254f/nova/scheduler/utils.py#L351

And I think we can fix that RT wrinkle as a separate bug because the same person confirmed that 'openstack resource provider allocation show' did not report DISK_GB allocations for the volume-backed server, which is the intent of *this* change.

We also know there are still issues with falsely failing disk claims on the compute if you have the DiskFilter enabled - which people using the CachingScheduler might still do since CachingScheduler doesn't use placement. I don't think that's going to get all fixed in a single change, and we can stack them as we go - we know we also need to handle this same logic for move operations as noted in the commit message."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-18 15:14:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-07-18 15:43:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

(4 comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-06 16:54:53.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid requesting DISK_GB allocation for root_gb on BFV instances

Right now, we still ask placement for a disk allocation covering
swap, ephemeral, and root disks for the instance even if the instance
is going to be volume-backed. This patch makes us not include the
root size in that calculation for placement, avoiding a false
failure because the volume size is counted against the compute's
available space.

To do this, we need another flag in request_spec to track the
BFV-ness of the instance. Right now, this patch just sets that on
new builds and the scheduler client assumes a lack of said flag
as "I don't know, so assume not-BFV" for compatibility. A
subsequent patch can calculate that flag for existing instances
so that we will be able to heal over time by migrating instances
or re-writing their allocations to reflect reality.

Change-Id: I9c2111f7377df65c1fc3c72323f85483b3295989
'}, {'created': '2018-07-06 19:43:05.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid requesting DISK_GB allocation for root_gb on BFV instances

swap, ephemeral, and root disks for the instance even if the instance
is going to be volume-backed. This patch makes us not include the
root size in that calculation for placement, avoiding a false
failure because the volume size is counted against the compute's
available space.

To do this, we need another flag in request_spec to track the
BFV-ness of the instance. Right now, this patch just sets that on
new builds and the scheduler client assumes a lack of said flag
as "I don't know, so assume not-BFV" for compatibility. A
subsequent patch can calculate that flag for existing instances
so that we will be able to heal over time by migrating instances
or re-writing their allocations to reflect reality.

Related-Bug: #1469179
Change-Id: I9c2111f7377df65c1fc3c72323f85483b3295989

commit_message:
Avoid requesting DISK_GB allocation for root_gb on BFV instances

Right now, we still ask placement for a disk allocation covering
swap, ephemeral, and root disks for the instance even if the instance
is going to be volume-backed. This patch makes us not include the
root size in that calculation for placement, avoiding a false
failure because the volume size is counted against the compute's
available space.

To do this, we need another flag in request_spec to track the
BFV-ness of the instance. Right now, this patch just sets that on
new builds and the scheduler client assumes a lack of said flag
as "I don't know, so assume not-BFV" for compatibility. A
subsequent patch can calculate that flag for existing instances
so that we will be able to heal over time by migrating instances
or re-writing their allocations to reflect reality.

Partial-Bug: #1469179
Change-Id: I9c2111f7377df65c1fc3c72323f85483b3295989

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-08 21:37:57.000000000', 'message': 'Properly track local root disk usage during moves

Change I0839470c4bcfb16590a0d87b306d683b059bf8a9 fixed
root disk usage tracking for volume-backed instances
when performing an instance_claim which happens during
the initial server create and unshelve. However, root
disk reporting is still wrong for volume-backed instances
during move claims (resize and evacuate) because a move
claim calls _update_usage_from_migration which passes a
Flavor object to ResourceTracker._get_usage_dict() and
that method didn't have "is_bfv" logic in that scenario.

This fixes the bug by always passing the instance object
to the _get_usage_dict() method so we can determine if
it's volume-backed and if so report the root_gb usage as 0.

The related functional regression test is updated
appropriately to show the bug is fixed for volume-backed
instances.

Change-Id: Ia19264ae7c88bb03ed3118795d4011ceb62ef92c
Closes-Bug: #1796737
'}]
commit_message:
Properly track local root disk usage during moves

Change I0839470c4bcfb16590a0d87b306d683b059bf8a9 fixed
root disk usage tracking for volume-backed instances
when performing an instance_claim which happens during
the initial server create and unshelve. However, root
disk reporting is still wrong for volume-backed instances
during move claims (resize and evacuate) because a move
claim calls _update_usage_from_migration which passes a
Flavor object to ResourceTracker._get_usage_dict() and
that method didn't have "is_bfv" logic in that scenario.

This fixes the bug by always passing the instance object
to the _get_usage_dict() method so we can determine if
it's volume-backed and if so report the root_gb usage as 0.

The related functional regression test is updated
appropriately to show the bug is fixed for volume-backed
instances.

Change-Id: Ia19264ae7c88bb03ed3118795d4011ceb62ef92c
Closes-Bug: #1796737

commit_message:
Set Tempest's service_available setting for congress

Tempest's service_available config option includes all the service
availability which is further used by tests to take decision of skip
or run the test.

For example, [service_available].congress is true then, congress test will run
or if [service_available].congress is false then, all congress related tests either
in telemetry tempest plugin or any other plugins will be skipped.

This commit add the setting of congress service[1] on congress devstack plugin.

Closes-Bug: #1743688
[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/congress-tempest-plugin/tree/congress_tempest_plugin/config.py#n24

Change-Id: I57de34d2b185b8e9838dd288d3673149391f0024

commit_message:
Enable deletion of deployment upon successful deployment

This change fixes an improper import that prevented the user from
seeing the delete deployment button if the deployment was successful.

Change-Id: I92a8980b5afb773cec0e97a4c457b8ce5dbc4e15
Story: 2004431
Task: 28092

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it

    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more

commit_message:
Add docker bridge ip option to the undercloud.conf

Add docker_bip option to the undercloud.conf in order
to easily override the value of: DockerNetworkOptions
through the undercloud.conf

Change-Id: Ibbf7c6101539bdf575c23295c1b9fa4bfc84cff7
(cherry picked from commit a22bb051903e2c84d47e93fbffd0c36e3a61b051)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-23 15:40:21.000000000', 'message': 'Remove spaces on variable NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS

This allows users to provide the list of extensions with spaces
in between. For example:

  NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS="ext1, ext2, ext3"

We will remove the spaces in between, so the result would be:

  "ext1,ext2,ext3"

This is because if the variable is provided by yaml (i.e. Zuul job)
and the list is too long so we want to break it into multiple lines.
Yaml will replace newline with space so we need to remove the space.

Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/619642/

Change-Id: Ib61dadd305a7e105633761ac92f6fdefbe039459
'}, {'created': '2018-11-23 16:34:49.000000000', 'message': 'Remove spaces on variable NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS

commit_message:
Remove spaces on variable NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS

This allows users to provide the list of extensions with spaces
in between. For example:

  NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS="ext1, ext2, ext3"

We will remove the spaces in between, so the result would be:

  "ext1,ext2,ext3"

This is because if the variable is provided by yaml (i.e. Zuul job)
and the list is too long so we want to break it into multiple lines.
Yaml will replace newline with space so we need to remove the space.

Needed-By: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/619642/

Change-Id: Ib61dadd305a7e105633761ac92f6fdefbe039459

(10 comments)

so the broad stroke of this make sense to me.

the behavior as written is probably what i would like to do by default
so because of that if we were to key it of the refesh time = 0 i would
also consider changing the default to 0

in the non 0 case i also think we should really consider introducing some jitter to smear the update form different compute nodes uniformly over the interval range. so the first time perioic task runs do something like this

import random
import thread
random.seed(compute uuid)
jitter = random.uniform(0,interval)
thread.sleep(jitter)
...

i think matt mentioned there is something in oslo to do this alreay for periodic task so if that is the case then the TODO i would is basicaly use oslo uniform distributed periodic task functionality to run this update.'}, {'account_id': 8768, 'date': '2018-11-02 15:16:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

I like the overall idea.  Got an early question though.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-11-02 16:12:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

Thanks for the early look, folks.

> the behavior as written is probably what i would like to do by default

Yes, maybe/probably, but in the future, after this has gotten some time in the field.

> in the non 0 case i also think we should really consider introducing some jitter

Good idea, but unrelated to this change.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-11-02 16:28:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-02 20:32:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Haven't had a chance to review this closely, but after reading the IRC logs, dropped some ideas on eric at http://p.anticdent.org/4euI

I think this is probably a good config option to have in non-nested worlds _and_ in non clustered virtdrivers. But in both of those scenarios we'll need to do something. Using generations more effectively as version identifiers might help limit calls."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-11-02 20:43:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Part of the reasoning behind the generations idea is to make it cheaper to check is a tree in placement is the same as the one we have, without have to rely on something like notifications (one of the ideas that came up in the irc conversation). I'd really prefer we not add oslo.messaging/notifications to placement if we can at all help it.

If there ever comes a time when we need subscription to resource provider activity, it would be better for it be more in the frame of etcd watchers."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-11-05 16:11:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2018-11-05 16:12:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Some of the tests failed in a way that we did not understand. Please help us classify these issues so that they can be part of Elastic Recheck http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/
For more details on this and other bugs, please see http://status.openstack.org/elastic-recheck/'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2018-11-28 22:18:37.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615606/ allows resource_provider_association_refresh to be zero (disable refresh)
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615646/ lets you SIGHUP the compute service to clear the cache manually
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615677/ reduces calls to placement from _ensure
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615695/ consolidates inventory refresh
- https://review.openstack.org/#/c/615705/ consolidates the _update code paths, allowing removal of a lot of cruft'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-01 23:06:33.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Trust the report client cache more

At the moment, this patch does a handful of things:

- On SIGHUP to the compute service, we'll now invalidate the report
  client's provider tree cache and reset the refresh timers.
  TODO: reno for this
- update_from_provider_tree now
  - is stop-on-first-failure, not best-effort
  - invalidates caches for providers in the whole tree surrounding the
    provider for which the failure was encountered. This is to ensure a
    clean slate for the next update. (See [1] for a scenario that
    justifies this change.)
  ...which means we needed to
- Add a new ProviderTree.remove_tree() method. The remove() method
  removed the specified node and its *sub*tree. In contrast, the
  remove_tree() method removes the entire tree around the specified
  node, and returns the UUIDs of all the removed nodes.
- Percolate the is_new_compute_node flag in the resource tracker down
  into _update_from_placement, and use it as a signal to decide whether
  to force _get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root to refresh.
- Make _get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root key off of whether the name
  kwarg was specified to decide whether the caller intended it to create
  the provider. If not, and the association refresh timer hasn't expired
  for the cached provider record, don't refresh it.
  TODO: This is too implicit; either make a new kwarg or split this into
        two methods (I think the latter).
  TODO: Remove the parent_provider_uuid kwarg. Were not using it.
- Start considering the root provider in the association refresh logic.
  Before, we were always doing the GET /rps?in_tree={u} call for that
  guy. Now we won't unless we think it's stale.
  TODO: Should this part of the change be based on a different conf
        option, and/or limited to when
        resource_provider_association_refresh == 0  ?
- Change the CONF.compute.resource_provider_association_refresh option
  to allow zero, meaning we *never* refresh (except on SIGHUP - see
  above).
  TODO: reno for this

TODO: Tests
TODO: Probably split this into multiple patches
TODO: ML discussion
TODO: Probably needs a bp/spec

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5a101e1417f492a549b0403f6fa61f5e55582f43/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L652

Change-Id: If7ab77b1a755d7ef40017c643610b8a5ce2abd5b
"}, {'created': '2018-11-05 16:11:25.000000000', 'message': "DNM: Trust the report client cache more

DNM: I'm going to rework this and split it up. Making this commit to
save my work for reference.

This reduces the number of calls made to placement by the resource
tracker's periodic update to refresh our local provider cache, and
allows for eliminating refreshing completely via config. The theory
being that:

- Placement should not be changing out of band, except for the cases
  noted below, so there's no need to keep refreshing the cache.
- Externally-owned child providers (e.g. neutron-owned bandwidth
  providers, cyborg-owned accelerator providers) are fully owned and
  managed by their owners. The compute service only cares about
  providers it owns, and doesn't even need to know about the others.
  (Except for purposes of scheduling, which doesn't use the cache.)
- Manual changes (e.g. via the CLI) can be followed up with a SIGHUP to
  the compute service to cause the cache to be refreshed.

At the moment, this patch does a handful of things, which may need to be
separated.

- On SIGHUP to the compute service, we'll now invalidate the report
  client's provider tree cache and reset the refresh timers.
  TODO: reno for this
- On failure, update_from_provider_tree now
  - raises right away, rather than trying to continue updating other
    pieces.
  - invalidates the entire provider cache rather than just the offending
    provider. This is to ensure a clean slate for the next update. (See
    [1] for a scenario that justifies this change.)
- Percolates the is_new_compute_node flag in the resource tracker down
  into _update_from_placement, and uses it as a signal to decide whether
  to ensure_resource_provider($compute). Otherwise we just use
  get_provider_tree (see below).
- Resolve the long-standing ugliness that was
  get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root by splitting it into
  - get_provider_tree, a read-only operation that refreshes the cache if
    refresh timers have expired, and returns a copy of it; and
  - ensure_resource_provider (which already existed, but was private).
- Start considering the root provider in the association refresh logic.
  Before, we were always doing the GET /rps?in_tree={u} call for that
  guy. Now we won't unless we think it's stale.
- Change the CONF.compute.resource_provider_association_refresh option
  to allow zero, meaning we *never* refresh (except on SIGHUP - see
  above).
  TODO: reno for this

There's an openstack-dev [2] / openstack-operators [3] email thread
discussing this.

TODO: Tests
TODO: Probably split this into multiple patches
TODO: Probably needs a bp/spec

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5a101e1417f492a549b0403f6fa61f5e55582f43/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L652

[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2018-November/016138.html

Change-Id: If7ab77b1a755d7ef40017c643610b8a5ce2abd5b

commit_message:
DNM: Trust the report client cache more

DNM: I'm going to rework this and split it up. Making this commit to
save my work for reference.

This reduces the number of calls made to placement by the resource
tracker's periodic update to refresh our local provider cache, and
allows for eliminating refreshing completely via config. The theory
being that:

- Placement should not be changing out of band, except for the cases
  noted below, so there's no need to keep refreshing the cache.
- Externally-owned child providers (e.g. neutron-owned bandwidth
  providers, cyborg-owned accelerator providers) are fully owned and
  managed by their owners. The compute service only cares about
  providers it owns, and doesn't even need to know about the others.
  (Except for purposes of scheduling, which doesn't use the cache.)
- Manual changes (e.g. via the CLI) can be followed up with a SIGHUP to
  the compute service to cause the cache to be refreshed.

At the moment, this patch does a handful of things, which may need to be
separated.

- On SIGHUP to the compute service, we'll now invalidate the report
  client's provider tree cache and reset the refresh timers.
  TODO: reno for this
- On failure, update_from_provider_tree now
  - raises right away, rather than trying to continue updating other
    pieces.
  - invalidates the entire provider cache rather than just the offending
    provider. This is to ensure a clean slate for the next update. (See
    [1] for a scenario that justifies this change.)
- Percolates the is_new_compute_node flag in the resource tracker down
  into _update_from_placement, and uses it as a signal to decide whether
  to ensure_resource_provider($compute). Otherwise we just use
  get_provider_tree (see below).
- Resolve the long-standing ugliness that was
  get_provider_tree_and_ensure_root by splitting it into
  - get_provider_tree, a read-only operation that refreshes the cache if
    refresh timers have expired, and returns a copy of it; and
  - ensure_resource_provider (which already existed, but was private).
- Start considering the root provider in the association refresh logic.
  Before, we were always doing the GET /rps?in_tree={u} call for that
  guy. Now we won't unless we think it's stale.
- Change the CONF.compute.resource_provider_association_refresh option
  to allow zero, meaning we *never* refresh (except on SIGHUP - see
  above).
  TODO: reno for this

There's an openstack-dev [2] / openstack-operators [3] email thread
discussing this.

TODO: Tests
TODO: Probably split this into multiple patches
TODO: Probably needs a bp/spec

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/5a101e1417f492a549b0403f6fa61f5e55582f43/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L652
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-November/136251.html
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2018-November/016138.html

Change-Id: If7ab77b1a755d7ef40017c643610b8a5ce2abd5b

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 27594, 'date': '2018-03-24 04:38:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-27 17:21:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

The cleanest / best solution to this is to add a volume action API to cinder for re-imaging the volume. Once that is available in a new cinder v3 microversion, nova can use it. The reason I think this should be done in Cinder with re-imaging the volume there is (1) it's cleaner from the nova side and (2) then Cinder is in control of how that re-image should happen, along with any details it needs to update, e.g. the volume's "volume_image_metadata" information would need to be updated.

We really don't want to do the volume create/delete/swap orchestration thing since that entails issues with the volume type being gone, going over quota, what to do about deleting the old volume, etc.

So please propose a spec to Cinder and start working the API changes there and then nova can depend on a new Cinder API.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-27 17:34:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Nova would likely have to create an empty attachment to the root volume so the volume stays reserved for the instance, then delete the old attachment and disconnect the volume from the host, call the new Cinder API to re-image the volume, and then nova could update the volume attachment with the host connector and complete it so the volume is again in-use. I think that would be the flow, similar to how volume-backed shelve and unshelve works today.'}, {'account_id': 27594, 'date': '2018-03-28 12:01:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

> The cleanest / best solution to this is to add a volume action API
 > to cinder for re-imaging the volume. Once that is available in a
 > new cinder v3 microversion, nova can use it. The reason I think
 > this should be done in Cinder with re-imaging the volume there is
 > (1) it's cleaner from the nova side and (2) then Cinder is in
 > control of how that re-image should happen, along with any details
 > it needs to update, e.g. the volume's "volume_image_metadata"
 > information would need to be updated.
 > 
 > We really don't want to do the volume create/delete/swap
 > orchestration thing since that entails issues with the volume type
 > being gone, going over quota, what to do about deleting the old
 > volume, etc.
 > 
 > So please propose a spec to Cinder and start working the API
 > changes there and then nova can depend on a new Cinder API.

Does the re-image operation means revert the image content to the volume?But if we re-image the original volume,the data which produced between taken the image and re-image the volume will be lost.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2018-03-28 12:18:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

> Does the re-image operation means revert the image content to the
 > volume?But if we re-image the original volume,the data which
 > produced between taken the image and re-image the volume will be
 > lost.

This is the definition of a rebuild.

volume-backed means we're storing the root disk in a cinder volume.
rebuild means reset the instance to its freshly installed state.

If a user rebuilds their server, they expect the contents of their root disk to be reset. It would be inconsistent and surprising if this behaviour differed based on where the root disk is located."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-03-28 22:24:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Right, what mdbooth said. If you want to preserve the data before doing the rebuild, then snapshot the instance prior to the rebuild.'}, {'account_id': 27615, 'date': '2018-09-13 15:16:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

typo'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-09-13 21:10:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

(2 comments)

There was agreement at the Stein PTG to support this feature but not with the proposed design. TommyLike is assigned to work on the new Cinder volume rebuild / re-image API so you'll need to coordinate with him on the dependency Cinder spec."}, {'account_id': 27594, 'date': '2018-09-14 01:10:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Well, if the user just want to use a new image to rebuild, we don't allow it?It is obviously unreasonable.In addition, to rebuild the image backed server doesn't limit the image if is new."}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2018-10-29 09:12:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(7 comments)

Comments inline, seems your implementation section does not contain enough details.'}, {'account_id': 20722, 'date': '2018-10-31 06:17:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

I think the spec is not clear to show what we will do in nova side, we need describe in detail to show the flow like [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/605317/4/specs/stein/add-volume-re-image-api.rst@50'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-31 18:15:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

> Well, if the user just want to use a new image to rebuild, we don't allow it?It is obviously unreasonable.In addition, to rebuild the image backed server doesn't limit the image if is new.

If the user attempts to rebuild a volume-backed server *today* with a new root image, the compute API fails with a 400 error, as you know. That is because the compute backend does not support swapping out the image in the root volume - that is what you are proposing to add in this blueprint. The reason we need a microversion is for interoperability, otherwise end users don't know which clouds support volume-backed rebuild with a new image and which don't. It is clearly a change in API behavior and therefore requires a microversion."}, {'account_id': 27594, 'date': '2018-11-02 09:26:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 27594, 'date': '2018-11-02 09:27:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

 > support volume-backed rebuild with a new image and which don't. It
 > is clearly a change in API behavior and therefore requires a
 > microversion.

Ok,thank you very much."}, {'account_id': 27594, 'date': '2018-11-02 10:20:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 12408, 'date': '2018-11-02 10:46:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27594, 'date': '2018-11-02 11:35:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

But the root volume is broken when the user want to use the rebuild action.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-02 14:57:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 12408, 'date': '2018-11-02 16:25:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: -Code-Review

> > (1 comment)

Not necessarily. User can want to call rebuild if a host is unavailable. Evacuation in nova is based on a rebuild call. And now there is no possibility to evacuate host containing volume backed VMs.'}, {'account_id': 12408, 'date': '2018-11-02 17:41:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Actually despite the spec states it is about support of volume backed  server rebuild it is about a special case only: volume-backed server in case a volume was created from an image. Let's be clear about it. There are other though that will remain unsupported."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-02 18:30:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

> Not necessarily. User can want to call rebuild if a host is unavailable. Evacuation in nova is based on a rebuild call. And now there is no possibility to evacuate host containing volume backed VMs.

I'm not following you here. Evacuate uses rebuild under the covers but the evacuate API does not take an image parameter, and evacuate certainly supports volume-backed servers. Is there some reason you think evacuate does not currently support volume-backed servers? Or maybe certain types of volumes (do vz volumes have a problem?)."}, {'account_id': 12408, 'date': '2018-11-02 22:45:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 12:

Well, looks I am wrong here. Sorry. I messed things up and was pretty sure evacuate requires image_ref while it doesn't. Just checked and found out that evacuate works pretty fine with vz volume backed VMs. Disregard please the said above by me."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-11-14 10:25:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Support volume-backed server rebuild

The spec is describing the operation of rebuild the volume-backed
server with a new image.

Spec for blueprint volume-backed-server-rebuild

Change-Id: I646041c872c4172219df2527820a672a0a2cb736

commit_message:
SUSE: Fix ceph packages for Leap 15

Ceph is python3-only in Leap 15 so we need to adjust the package names.

Change-Id: Ica80f6e69764ef46c4158e0c372e9a435ad49e50

commit_message:
Support fetching specific db column in OVO

This commit introduces a new method 'get_values' in
neutron_lib.db.model_query module. Callers can leverage
this method to fetch specific field of a OVO.

Related patch in Neutron: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/610182/

Change-Id: I524c7101fa2dcbc5bd78587bf1fc8107faca70b5

commit_message:
Install UEFI related package for nova image

- for x86_64 arch, install OVMF for RHEL family and ovmf for Debian
  family
- for aarch64 arch, install AAVMF for RHEL family and qemu-efi for
  Debian family
- there is no package support for ppc64le

Closes-Bug: #1796558
Change-Id: Ie1c688e74ec2aa3b6169c0a18a856dd0c92fe443
(cherry picked from commit 60009339827ff81537d80f6a6d3dfa23ad36dbf1)

commit_message:
Install UEFI related package for nova image

- for x86_64 arch, install OVMF for RHEL family and ovmf for Debian
  family
- for aarch64 arch, install AAVMF for RHEL family and qemu-efi for
  Debian family
- there is no package support for ppc64le

Closes-Bug: #1796558
Change-Id: Ie1c688e74ec2aa3b6169c0a18a856dd0c92fe443
(cherry picked from commit 60009339827ff81537d80f6a6d3dfa23ad36dbf1)

commit_message:
Replace deprecated "decodestring()" by "decodebytes()"

decodestring() is deprecated alias of decodebytes()
https://docs.python.org/3/library/base64.html#base64.decodestring

The same has been done for nova:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/610401/

Change-Id: Ie069aaaff1646a70f3717fc6f9c7252949c4e5fd

[{'created': '2018-11-15 12:42:17.000000000', 'message': "api-ref: document encryption type provider choices

This updates the encrypted volume type provider
parameter descriptions for the create and update
requests to note the two choices of 'luks' and 'plain'.
Since we don't want those choices in the response
parameter descriptions, the parameters have to be
broken down a bit in the parameters.yaml file to
be request/response and optional/required.

There are currently other supported values for the
encryption type provider, including the legacy
classpath values, but we want people using the
non-legacy values so only luks and plain are
documented here, and luks is marked as the
recommended choice over plain (dm-crypt).

Change-Id: I496d30ecf6390f51cdd8e547b7345b3da30e92de
Closes-Bug: #1803513
"}]
commit_message:
api-ref: document encryption type provider choices

This updates the encrypted volume type provider
parameter descriptions for the create and update
requests to note the two choices of 'luks' and 'plain'.
Since we don't want those choices in the response
parameter descriptions, the parameters have to be
broken down a bit in the parameters.yaml file to
be request/response and optional/required.

There are currently other supported values for the
encryption type provider, including the legacy
classpath values, but we want people using the
non-legacy values so only luks and plain are
documented here, and luks is marked as the
recommended choice over plain (dm-crypt).

Change-Id: I496d30ecf6390f51cdd8e547b7345b3da30e92de
Closes-Bug: #1803513

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-15 08:51:39.000000000', 'message': 'horizon: regenerate compressed javascript and css on configuration changes

previously, the horizon container would not re-rerun the manage.py
collectstatic/compress tasks when configuration files in
/etc/openstack-dashboard/local-settings.d were modified (or added or
deleted).  This commit modifies the checksum calculation to take all
configuration files into account.

Closes-bug: 1778963
Change-Id: I6946ab96cd758ef6eed56c9c4130046ac884b5e3
(cherry picked from commit 863f565b08867b87f3df7d1fc091ac26be90a1e8)
'}]
commit_message:
horizon: regenerate compressed javascript and css on configuration changes

previously, the horizon container would not re-rerun the manage.py
collectstatic/compress tasks when configuration files in
/etc/openstack-dashboard/local-settings.d were modified (or added or
deleted).  This commit modifies the checksum calculation to take all
configuration files into account.

Closes-bug: 1778963
Change-Id: I6946ab96cd758ef6eed56c9c4130046ac884b5e3
(cherry picked from commit 863f565b08867b87f3df7d1fc091ac26be90a1e8)

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Closes-Bug:  #1801691

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-05 14:33:59.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Add zuul jobs for image building

This will add the image building into zuul.d folder.

Each folder will be a series of images to build. Inside the
folders, a build.sh shell script shall be responsible for building
the images for all openstack branches.

Each job will be focusing on their own images, in order to avoid
useless rebuild of images.

A job will be required per distribution.

Change-Id: I2d01e3f2c34d6dd7db4a1c3897dc4b994bf02623

'}, {'created': '2018-11-21 16:20:05.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Add zuul jobs for image building

This will add the image building into zuul.d folder.

Each folder will be a series of images to build. Inside the
folders, Dockerfiles, with different names per distribution.

A script can be introduced in the future (Makefile) to build
one or multiple of those images, but this isn't part of this
commit.

Each job will be focusing on their own images, in order to avoid
useless rebuild of images.

A job will be required per distribution.

Change-Id: I2d01e3f2c34d6dd7db4a1c3897dc4b994bf02623

Change-Id: I2d01e3f2c34d6dd7db4a1c3897dc4b994bf02623
"}, {'created': '2018-11-22 14:59:03.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Add zuul jobs for image building

This patch adds image building process.

Each folder will contain a 'kind' of images to build. Each folder will
have a parent job. Inheritence of the parent job per folder will be used
to have distribution variants (centos_7, ubuntu_xenial, opensuse_15).

Folders containing Dockerfiles (a different Dockerfiles per
distribution), will be able to call the docker building play
(docker-build.yml).

A script can be introduced in a later patchset, to introduce a global
building feature, which will build ALL the image for users for a given
distribution, using a Makefile.

Change-Id: I2d01e3f2c34d6dd7db4a1c3897dc4b994bf02623
"}, {'created': '2018-11-23 10:44:30.000000000', 'message': 'Add build process and osh-infra images

This patch adds image building process.

Each folder will contain a 'kind' of images to build. Each folder will
have a parent job. Inheritence of the parent job per folder will be used
to have distribution variants (centos_7, ubuntu_xenial, opensuse_15).

Folders containing Dockerfiles (a different Dockerfiles per
distribution), will be able to call the docker building play
(docker-build.yml).

A script can be introduced in a later patchset, to introduce a global
building feature, which will build ALL the image for users for a given
distribution, using a Makefile.

Dockerfiles come from openstack-helm-infra repos, but with the
following changes:
* The deprecated "MAINTAINER" directive has been replaced with
  LABEL maintainer=<maintaineremail>
* If Dockerfiles' default arguments were mismatching the
  documentation or Makefiles, they were adapted (see libvirt).

Each folder is given a convenience build script, to locally build
only one image. That script gets included to avoid repeating
ourselves in the documentation.

Change-Id: I2d01e3f2c34d6dd7db4a1c3897dc4b994bf02623

'}, {'created': '2018-11-24 10:28:06.000000000', 'message': 'Add build process and osh-infra images

This patch adds image building process for OSH.

Each root folder contains a 'kind' of images to build. Each folder will
have its own parent job, inheriting from a 'openstack-helm-images-base'
job. The folder 'parent job' is used for building distribution
variants (centos_7, ubuntu_xenial, opensuse_15).

Folders containing Dockerfiles (a different Dockerfiles per
distribution) will use the docker building play (docker-build.yml).

Dockerfiles come from openstack-helm-infra repository,
with the following changes:
* The deprecated "MAINTAINER" directive has been replaced with
  LABEL maintainer=<maintaineremail>
* If Dockerfiles' default arguments were mismatching the
  documentation or Makefiles, they were adapted (see libvirt).
* Relative paths to the openstack-helm-infra repo have been removed.

Each folder is given a convenience build script (build.sh) which
can be used to build a specific image.
This script's content gets included in the documentation to avoid
duplications of content.

This patch focuses on each image separately.
Another patch will be added to deal with a repo-wide image building
process, whether for CI purposes, or for developer's purposes,
with the help of a Makefile.

Note: The kubeadm-aio image building is currently broken, due to
its reliance on the openstack-helm-infra charts to be built.
It means we have circular dependencies, and those need to be
figured out in a different commit.

Change-Id: I2d01e3f2c34d6dd7db4a1c3897dc4b994bf02623

* Relative paths to the openstack-helm-infra repo have been removed.

Each folder is given a convenience build script (build.sh) which
can be used to build a specific image.
This script's content gets included in the documentation to avoid
duplications of content.

This patch focuses on each image separately.
Another patch will be added to deal with a repo-wide image building
process, whether for CI purposes, or for developer's purposes,
with the help of a Makefile.

Note: The kubeadm-aio image building is currently broken, due to
its reliance on the openstack-helm-infra charts to be built.
It means we have circular dependencies, and those need to be
figured out in a different commit.

Change-Id: I2d01e3f2c34d6dd7db4a1c3897dc4b994bf02623

commit_message:
Add build process and osh-infra images

This patch adds image building process for OSH.

Each root folder contains a 'kind' of images to build. Each folder will
have its own parent job, inheriting from a 'openstack-helm-images-base'
job. The folder 'parent job' is used for building distribution
variants (centos_7, ubuntu_xenial, opensuse_15).

Folders containing Dockerfiles (a different Dockerfiles per
distribution) will use the docker building play (docker-build.yml).

Dockerfiles come from openstack-helm-infra repository,
with the following changes:
* The deprecated "MAINTAINER" directive has been replaced with
  LABEL maintainer=<maintaineremail>
* If Dockerfiles' default arguments were mismatching the
  documentation or Makefiles, they were adapted (see libvirt).
* Relative paths to the openstack-helm-infra repo have been removed.

Each folder is given a convenience build script (build.sh) which
can be used to build a specific image manually.

This script's content gets included in the documentation to avoid
duplications of content.

This patch focuses on each image separately.

Another patch will be added to deal with a repo-wide image building
process, whether for CI purposes, or for developer's purposes,
with the help of a Makefile.

Note: Kubeadm-aio image was not imported in this process due to
circular dependencies: Image building currently requires the
helm charts of openstack-helm-infra.

Change-Id: I2d01e3f2c34d6dd7db4a1c3897dc4b994bf02623

should use "http://[' + mgmt_ip + ']:' + str(port)"

commit_message:
fixed http ping vnf support ipv6

Now monitor the VNF. If the VNF address is IPV6,
it cannot use "http://' + mgmt_ip + ':' + str(port)",
should use "http://[' + mgmt_ip + ']:' + str(port)"

Change-Id: Ie6e4e9342cea396dc6b4bb77680c59d7cc3b177d

messages: [{'account_id': 27181, 'date': '2018-11-27 06:21:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19644, 'date': '2018-11-27 13:05:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 29339, 'date': '2018-11-28 11:20:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26222, 'date': '2018-11-28 18:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-27 06:21:58.000000000', 'message': 'fixed zabbix url support ipv6

Now monitor the VNF. If the zabbix address is IPV6,
it cannot use "http://ip:port",
should use "http://[ip]:port"

Change-Id: I5bebb959578f2b7007416aa2bf817565fe364afe
'}]
commit_message:
fixed zabbix url support ipv6

Now monitor the VNF. If the zabbix address is IPV6,
it cannot use "http://ip:port",
should use "http://[ip]:port"

Change-Id: I5bebb959578f2b7007416aa2bf817565fe364afe

commit_message:
Fix the horizon failed to start

Currently, Horzion container fails to start when enabled designate,
murano, magnum and so on. This patch is to fix it.

Change-Id: I32da6dc1a65d3bfcaa59b4c9136e389af1f9b551
Closes-Bug: #1744428
(cherry picked from commit 8ab42604186064d61a6b9a024a37ade1f885f204)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

commit_message:
Give drop_move_claim() correct docstring

Previously, there was a just a comment about removing usage on the
destination node. This is incorrect: usage is removed on the compute
host specified by the nodename parameter to the method. This patch
corrects this in a proper docstring.

Change-Id: I2f676966136a78bb9600626852584f838cb08c5b

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-29 23:49:59.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I3b69f534e327ca2d49c5da668192d316eafda30c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I3b69f534e327ca2d49c5da668192d316eafda30c
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-27 18:48:22.000000000', 'message': 'Allow user/group to be overriden in unit section

The unit section allows for user/group to be set via global variable
however in some cases a specific unit may need to have a different
user/group setup. This change allows for the users to be defined in the
service definition and falls back to the global default.

Change-Id: I69540efd2c993912b042a1b6b6a1dc279542f325
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit f79988efcadee3da7c68619de88d0d9ec74fa837)
'}]
commit_message:
Allow user/group to be overriden in unit section

The unit section allows for user/group to be set via global variable
however in some cases a specific unit may need to have a different
user/group setup. This change allows for the users to be defined in the
service definition and falls back to the global default.

Change-Id: I69540efd2c993912b042a1b6b6a1dc279542f325
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit f79988efcadee3da7c68619de88d0d9ec74fa837)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-21 19:35:47.000000000', 'message': "Maintain private interface for loopingcall._ThreadingEvent

A previous patch replaced the _Event() function and _ThreadingEvent()
class in oslo_service.loopingcall with a single _Event() class. However,
some consumers of oslo_service (including Nova) were relying on the
private interface to mock methods during unit testing, which prevents
them updating to the latest version of oslo.service.

Make '_ThreadingEvent' a reference to the _Event class, so that the
private interface does not change.

This is a stable-only change, because on master we now require consumers
to use oslo_service.fixture.SleepFixture rather than rely on the private
interface.

Change-Id: I37b38c8e1382cdf28a533dfcfc017d238c3f2684
Related-Bug: #1798774

commit_message:
Maintain private interface for loopingcall._ThreadingEvent

A previous patch replaced the _Event() function and _ThreadingEvent()
class in oslo_service.loopingcall with a single _Event() class. However,
some consumers of oslo_service (including Nova) were relying on the
private interface to mock methods during unit testing, which prevents
them updating to the latest version of oslo.service.

Make '_ThreadingEvent' a reference to the _Event class, and add
deprecated methods compatible with the previous interface, so that the
private interface does not change.

This is a stable-only change, because on master we now require consumers
to use oslo_service.fixture.SleepFixture rather than rely on the private
interface.

Change-Id: I37b38c8e1382cdf28a533dfcfc017d238c3f2684
Related-Bug: #1798774

commit_message:
Implement domain-scope for context objects

The OpenStack identity sevice issues domain-scoped tokens and
keystonemiddlware sets a specific header when it validates a
domain-scoped token. This commit allows context objects to set
domain_id attributes for tokens scoped to a domain and also processes
the domain ID header from keystonemiddlware.

Change-Id: I620d647499abaf5a7103d82af22a190fcc0b3fae

commit_message:
Add quota readiness check to controller

Currently, if the number of neutron resources requested reaches
the quota, kuryr-controller is marked as unhealthy and restarted.
In order to avoid the constant restart of the pod, this patch adds
a new readiness checks that checks if the resources used by
the enabled handlers are over quota.

Closes-Bug: 1804310
Change-Id: If4d42f866d2d64cae63736f4c206bedca039258b

Felipe, I don't agree, the "List available zones" action has its own policy "get_available_zones", so this is correct way to test in this case. Patrole already has many similar tests, like compute.FloatingIpsBulkRbacTest.test_list_floating_ips_bulk, identity.v3.IdentityAuthV3RbacTest.test_list_auth_domain
My opinion is if there is a special policy for list action, then we can test it like here otherwise we need to use override_role_and_validate_list function'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2018-10-23 18:04:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

This commit includes list available zones tests for RBAC

> (3 comments)

```
    @contextmanager
    def override_role_and_validate_list(self, test_obj, method, resource_name,
                                        resources=None, resource_id=None):
        def decor(fn):
            def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
                res = fn(*args, **kwargs)
                ctx.resources = res[resource_name]
                return res
            return wrapper

        original_list_method = method
        setattr(method.im_self,
                method.im_func.func_name, decor(original_list_method))

        ctx = ValidateListContext(resources, resource_id)
        with self.override_role(test_obj):
            yield ctx
            ctx.validate()

        setattr(client, method_name, original_list_method)
```

Some rework is done to remove redundant param. Need to think on how to drop ``resource_name``.
I bet it should be somewhere so we do not need to specify it.'}, {'account_id': 8911, 'date': '2018-11-09 22:46:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14:

commit_message:
Helper for validating RBAC list actions

List RBAC actions typically perform soft authorization checks meaning
that the response bodies omit resources that the user isn't authorized
to see.
For example, if an admin user creates a user, member role might not be
able to see that user when listing all the users in a tenant,
depending on the RBAC rule.
This patch set adds override_role_and_validate_list function to
RbacUtils to validate RBAC flows for API list actions.

Change-Id: I5f39efc8aa0004d4ad435cbd6b8fb037c33832d6

If the operator is using an activation key, the repositories that are

We can't specify rhsm_repos parameter if you are using rhsm_activation_key.
Otherwise, if you we rhsm_username and rhsm_password, we can use rhsm_repos

commit_message:
Make it more explicit that rhsm_activation_key and rhsm_repos are exclusive

If the operator is using an activation key, the repositories that are
associated to the subscription are configured in the Red Hat portal or in the
local instance of Satellite if any.
We can't specify rhsm_repos parameter if you are using rhsm_activation_key.
Otherwise, if you we rhsm_username and rhsm_password, we can use rhsm_repos
to select which parameters are deployed.

This patch:
- adds a debug message in the tasks/main when both options are defined.
- documents this situation in the README.
- adds 2 use cases in the README, one with Satellite and one with
  Portal.

Change-Id: I6448d2f7258c2b00b8617f8e12fd06b53d28dc83

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-23 14:11:59.000000000', 'message': 'Add puppet-tripleo image

This is a base for the tripleoclient image, and it is also used by
TripleO deployment steps, when configuring containers with puppet.

This allows to keep puppet-tripleo that pulls in the hole openstack
puppet modules (and not only) world, out of the base container images,
effectively reducing the containers images size for TripleO.

Related-Bug: #1804822

Change-Id: Ie83a1e11adb0ae3f26318031eb5ba433f78d24cb
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-11-26 11:03:31.000000000', 'message': 'Add a source puppet-tripleo image on top of base

Provides a base for the tripleoclient image, and it is also used by
TripleO deployment steps, when configuring containers with puppet.

Do not build the tripleoclient on top of openstack-base, it pulls in
the hole world, that is not needed to just allow the tripleo client
functioning. All of its real dependencies will be instead ensured
via the tripleo client package dependencies.

So the resulting build chain becomes:

* base -> puppet-tripleo -> tripleoclient (nothing is dulplicated in
  the layers)

instead of maintaining both as:

* base -> puppet-tripleo
* base -> openstack-base -> tripleoclient (duiplicates puppet-tripleo)

This also allows to keep puppet-tripleo that pulls in the hole
openstack puppet modules (and not only) world, out of the base
container images, effectively reducing the containers images size for
TripleO.

Related-Bug: #1804822

Change-Id: Ie83a1e11adb0ae3f26318031eb5ba433f78d24cb
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-11-27 12:41:06.000000000', 'message': 'Add a source puppet-tripleo image

It is needed for TripleO deployment steps, when configuring
containers with puppet.

This also allows to keep puppet-tripleo that pulls in the hole
openstack puppet modules (and puppet/ruby/systemd) worlds, out of the
base container images, effectively reducing the containers images size
for TripleO and CVEs to maintain for unrelated components that have
nothing to TripleO not OpenStack, like ruby or systemd or puppet
itself.

Related-Bug: #1804822

Change-Id: Ie83a1e11adb0ae3f26318031eb5ba433f78d24cb
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-11-27 12:41:58.000000000', 'message': 'Add a source puppet-tripleo image

'}]
commit_message:
Add a source puppet-tripleo image

It is needed for TripleO deployment steps, when configuring
containers with puppet.

This also allows to keep puppet-tripleo that pulls in the hole
openstack puppet modules (and puppet/ruby/systemd) worlds, out of the
base container images, effectively reducing the containers images size
for TripleO and CVEs to maintain for unrelated components that have
nothing to TripleO nor to OpenStack, like ruby or systemd or puppet
itself.

Related-Bug: #1804822

Change-Id: Ie83a1e11adb0ae3f26318031eb5ba433f78d24cb
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
