(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-11-27 17:28:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2

I think we are on the wrong track here. The reason puppet is in the base layer of our current images is that it de-duplicates downloading the same binaries multiple times. (It saves network and disk space).

It is true that a change to puppet in the base layer might cause you to have to rebuild all of the child containers which layer on top of it. This is just how base containers work. If we wanted to put puppet in the child layers we could but this would make our set of containers much larger in fact because we would essentially have multiple copies of puppet for each service.

Regarding the bind mounting of /usr/share/openstack-puppet-modules from the host this is a remnant of the past partially. Keep in mind that our containers architecture was built as a hybrid baremetal/containers architecture which supported both baremetal and containerized services. Today most services have been containers.... except for Pacemaker. Also, there is an option to extra a tarball from swift onto the host system, which could contain puppet modules. (Deployment Artifacts). But I don't think deployment artifacts is used much, and it isn't really needed with containers.

Also, keep in mind that I've had a patch up to consume puppet from within the containers for quite a while: I73026e66bcfafd1c582916141b5b1cf0ce0dc36c The reason for this patch would be to work with a zero footprint installer where you literally wanted nothing on the host. Obviously this would exclude pacemaker.

Regardless, I think the assertions in this commit message are off base with regards to the focus on puppet, ruby, etc. They apply to all the packages in the base container right, not just the ones you've singled out here.

Lastly and perhaps most importantly like I said on IRC the side car container pattern you mention is being used incorrectly here I think. You should never be bind mounting or using --volumes from for applications or libaries. This goes against the spirit of containers (which should be self contained!). I think rather the side care pattern for --volumes from would be to share application *DATA* only. Each container should always have its own binaries, libraries, etc and having RPM check these dependencies for us is ideal. That said, there are perhaps future container Filesystems which would allow us to consume some system binaries from the host I think. Perhaps this is what you are after here...

Add all this up: Puppet won't run unless its in the service containers as our modules requires access to the per service config files. And bind mounting or using --volumes-from to obtain the Puppet applications and binaries is not a good idea as it violates our containers. I don't think we want to pursue this pattern."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2018-11-28 04:19:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 10:58:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Alex and Dan, PTAL the updated https://review.openstack.org/#/c/620310.
The size (we are talking of like a 200MB cut off for each container, which is like 30% of size) and security aspects it's aiming to fix worth a consideration at least. Please consider removing -2. Though implementation is discussable, I see no reasons to block it."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 11:00:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> It is true that a change to puppet in the base layer might cause you to have to rebuild all of the child containers which layer on top of it. This is just how base containers work. If we wanted to put puppet in the child layers we could but this would make our set of containers much larger in fact because we would essentially have multiple copies of puppet for each service.

That is not only puppet, but its (and not only) dependencies like very heavy and rich for often CVE fixes to maintain, systemd. Secondly, we are not aiming to add puppet into each container, only to a single puppet-tripleo config image.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 11:26:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 11:33:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 11:33:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 11:34:12.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bug/1804822 to base-container-reduction'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 16:33:57.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This goes against the spirit of containers (which should be self contained)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-26 13:56:04.000000000', 'message': 'Optimize config containers used for puppet steps

Currently, we include puppet-tripleo into the base container image,
which affects the size of all containers for all services. Then tht
configures services with puppet via FooConfigImage images defaulting
to their main service images.

Keeping the puppet bits in the service images adds approximately 16MB
to the base layer. We use like a 101 images for a typical deployment,
having a 146 of total images. For edge scenarios, where there are
potentially (tens of) thousands nodes distributed over high latency
and limited bandwidth WAN networks, that poses a problem.

To improve that, use a single DockerPuppetTripleoImage image,
which contains puppet-tripleo with its dependencies, to configure
containerized services via puppet* deployment steps. That image may
still be overriden via customizable FooConfigImage, so that keeps this
change a backwards compatible.

Closes-Bug: #1804822
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/619744

Change-Id: I88ff623ca4d712ae81769ad2d95af220fffb1682
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2018-11-28 11:26:47.000000000', 'message': 'Optimize config containers used for puppet steps

Currently, we include puppet-tripleo and its dependencies, like puppet,
  which also pulls in ruby, systemd and more of it into the base
  container image.

That self-containing architecture of containers badly affects:

* the size of the base layer and all containers images as an
  additional 300MB (adds an extra 30% of size).
* Edge cases, where we have containers images to be distributed, at
  least once to hit local registries, over high-latency and limited
  bandwith, highly unreliable WAN connections.
* numbers of packages to update in CI for all containers for all
  services (CI jobs do not rebuild containers so each container gets
  updated for those 300MB of extra size).
* security and the surface of attacks, by introducing systemd et al as
  additional subjects for CVE fixes to maintain for all containers.
* services uptime, by additional restarts of services related to
  security maintanence of irrelevant to openstack components sitting
  as a dead weight in containers images for ever.

To improve that, consume puppet et al bits from a side car container
created from the given DockerPuppetTripleoImage image. That effectively
"merges" runtime the individual services config containers and puppet
binaries/ manifests, introducing a Virtual Configuration Management Pod
abstraction.

Technically we could instead use native podman pods for that, but
currently let's stick to --volumes-from as we potentially may want to
have it backported for long time releases for better supporting of Edge
scenarios, like Distributed Compute Node (DCN).

Alternatively, we could do that "merging" build-time, in layers, by
splitting the config- vs runtime- services container images. But that
would buy nothing neither for the end size (it only would become more
images to fetch), nor security (more images to maintain and config
images would still have to be patched for unrelated, like systemd,
things) of images.

Co-Authored-By: Thomas Herv√© <therve@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1804822
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/620061

Change-Id: I88ff623ca4d712ae81769ad2d95af220fffb1682
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Optimize config containers used for puppet steps

Currently, we include puppet-tripleo and its dependencies, like puppet,
  which also pulls in ruby, systemd and more of it into the base
  container image.

That self-containing architecture of containers badly affects:

* the size of the base layer and all containers images as an
  additional 300MB (adds an extra 30% of size).
* Edge cases, where we have containers images to be distributed, at
  least once to hit local registries, over high-latency and limited
  bandwith, highly unreliable WAN connections.
* numbers of packages to update in CI for all containers for all
  services (CI jobs do not rebuild containers so each container gets
  updated for those 300MB of extra size).
* security and the surface of attacks, by introducing systemd et al as
  additional subjects for CVE fixes to maintain for all containers.
* services uptime, by additional restarts of services related to
  security maintanence of irrelevant to openstack components sitting
  as a dead weight in containers images for ever.

To improve that, consume puppet et al bits from a side car container
created from the given DockerPuppetTripleoImage image. That effectively
"merges" runtime the individual services config containers and puppet
binaries/ manifests, introducing a Virtual Configuration Management Pod
abstraction.

Technically we could instead use native podman pods for that, but
currently let's stick to --volumes-from as we potentially may want to
have it backported for long time releases for better supporting of Edge
scenarios, like Distributed Compute Node (DCN).

Alternatively, we could do that "merging" build-time, in layers, by
splitting the config- vs runtime- services container images. But that
would buy nothing neither for the end size (it only would become more
images to fetch), nor security (more images to maintain and config
images would still have to be patched for unrelated, like systemd,
things) of images.

Co-Authored-By: Thomas Herv√© <therve@redhat.com>
Partial-Bug: #1804822
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/619744

Change-Id: I88ff623ca4d712ae81769ad2d95af220fffb1682
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Optimize base and upper layer for containers

* Do not add puppet et al bits into the base image layer.
* Remove packages dependencies systemd/systemd-libs/dbus from all
  containers via Kolla footers, unless it will be fixed at the
  packaging level.

That reduces the size of the base layer and end images a lot
(more than 280MB), and also improves security as it cuts off
future maintenance for unrelated components.

We have to keep ruby yet in the base layer, for side-car config
containers working alongside config images in t-h-t (see the
dependency change for details).

Alternatively, we could split config vs runtime services container images,
but that would buy nothing neither for the end size (it only would
become more things to fetch), nor security (config images would still
have to be patched for unrelated, like systemd, things) of images.

Change-Id: I460f8e4ca36791d526d559c87653135717f6f4ec
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/620061
Closes-Bug: #1804822

[{'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-23 14:55:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-23 15:00:12.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/zero-footprint to base-container-reduction'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-23 15:22:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-26 11:08:23.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/zero-footprint to base-container-reduction'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-26 11:23:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-26 11:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/zero-footprint to base-container-reduction'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-26 14:01:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/619736/ (kolla)
Shall I add it to the commit msg? Afaik that is pointless, we do not build kolla images in CI, only consuming those from the promoted ones.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-26 14:54:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-26 14:54:33.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/zero-footprint to base-container-reduction'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-11-26 16:05:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I'm not sure this is going to work right because I think there may be some dependency on software from the regular containers that is going to be needed by the puppet containers. I'm not sure this solves what is being proposed either."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-26 16:14:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Alex, let's try and see?
Not sure what did you mean for the latter part? It saves 16MB at least for each of the images we deploy. Some calculations done in the subject mail thread and in the bug 1804822"}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-11-26 16:25:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

No it doesn't. That 16M is in a single layer that is shared by all containers. It's not 16M*containers, it's just 16M to the layer from the base container."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-26 16:28:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

what about CI package update impact? it saves all the update delta for each of the used ~101 containers, as we update all puppet* RPMs not in the base layer.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-26 16:52:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

We cannot just switch the config image to a single DockerPuppetTripleoImage for all containers. Let's back to a side car container and using --volumes-from it then."}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2018-11-26 18:53:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-2

A couple of things I don't like about this:

-first, rather than using a more complex mechanism to containerize the puppet module (requiring bind mounting from one container to another) I would rather decouple the puppet packages from puppet-tripleo. In this manner you could have each service container self contain its own relevant puppet modules. For example: keystone would require puppet-keystone only. A separate puppet-tripleo package could be generated which doesn't install all the dependencies, and thus each container would be lightweight.

-second: the ConfigImage parameters here are used by docker-puppet.py to optimize how the configuration runs for each service. Each puppet run must use the service container itself. For some services we optimize the run so that the config files for all related services (cinder-* for example) are generated in a single run. I think you are breaking that feature here."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-27 09:52:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Thank you for inputs Dan. You're right.

Decoupling is proposed here https://review.rdoproject.org/17517/.

And yes, I'm going to keep the ConfigImage logic intact."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-27 10:17:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Dan, wrt 

> rather than using a more complex mechanism to containerize the puppet module (requiring bind mounting from one container to another) I would rather decouple the puppet packages from puppet-tripleo.

I'm not sure what decoupling buys for us to avoid bind mounting of *puppet* from one container to another... I can see how decoupling allows keep including puppet-tripleo w/o puppet into the base layer, but still cannot get it what to do with missing puppet in the base layer :)"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-27 12:36:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-27 12:46:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-27 12:46:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

@Dan, I didn't get the idea with decoupling and that it buys for us when thinking of removing puppet et al from the end images for openstack services"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-27 12:51:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Dan, I think the decoupling idea is great, but it has nothing to the reference bug and aims to solve/improve something different. We'll need side car containers, think of it as pods, sooner or later, that is, to decouple puppet et al from the base layer and from all of the images we produce and maintain for OpenStack in TripleO. Mind removing -2 please?"}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-27 12:52:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-27 13:02:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 10:54:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 10:56:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

@Dan please see the upper patch on top.
The size and security aspects it's aiming to fix worth a consideration at least. Please consider removing -2. Though implementation is discussable, I see no reasons to block it."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 11:38:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 11:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Workflow-1

needs https://review.openstack.org/619736'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2018-11-28 16:33:37.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

This goes against the spirit of containers (which should be self contained)'}]

commit_message:
Add puppet-tripleo container

Define DockerPuppetTripleoImage to be used as a side car source
container with all puppet bits to be used alongside the services
config images, when configuring services in t-h-t deployment steps.

The t-h-t service for puppet-tripleo will likely be a noop so that
we can simply use the existing 'overcloud container image prepare'
commands to obtain this new container.

Additionally, remove systemd/systemd-libs/dbus installed via RPM
dependencies of puppet as we do not want to maintain it and it is not
needed for containers. That is due to security and size of end images
reasons.

Related-Bug: #1804822

Change-Id: If7b106cd757378ec7a71778eef5b3a8199dbc77a
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2018-11-26 22:51:22.000000000', 'message': 'sat6: pull & deploy katello certs

For a node to communicate correctly with Katello, it needs the right SSL
certificates in place, and facts configured in RHSM.

It is provided by katello-ca-consumer-latest.noarch.rpm with
katello-rhsm-consumer script.

This patch installs the rpm and runs the script.

Change-Id: I180eb65a01832da76d5c433d9b13f8e410e24d04
Closes-Bug: #1805249
'}, {'created': '2018-11-26 23:08:33.000000000', 'message': 'sat6: pull & deploy katello certs

commit_message:
sat6: pull & deploy katello certs

For a node to communicate correctly with Katello, it needs the right SSL
certificates in place, and facts configured in RHSM.

It is provided by katello-ca-consumer-latest.noarch.rpm with
katello-rhsm-consumer script.

This patch installs the rpm and runs the script.

Change-Id: I180eb65a01832da76d5c433d9b13f8e410e24d04
Closes-Bug: #1805249

I like the idea of dropping xxxDetails objects very much. I also think they make life more complicated as it should.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-11-28 14:14:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Let's do this everywhere."}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-22 14:59:40.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Change approach to detailed listings of baremetal resources

The current approach with separate ResourceDetail classes suffers
from serious flows and is barely usable. For example for nodes:
* get_node() returns complete Node objects
* nodes() returns incomplete Node objects
* nodes(details=True) returns NodeDetail objects, which are exactly
  like complete Node objects, except that you cannot do anything
  with them: updating, listing VIFs, etc.

This change consolidates everything into Node (Port, etc) objects
and deprecates NodeDetail (PortDetail, etc). I would highly recommend
the same approach taken for other ResourceDetail objects.

Change-Id: Idedee2b394e2ed412a69880d4bc9315737e1c3ed
'}, {'created': '2018-11-23 08:15:00.000000000', 'message': 'Change approach to detailed listings of baremetal resources

The current approach with separate ResourceDetail classes suffers
from serious flows and is barely usable. For example for nodes:
* get_node() returns complete Node objects
* nodes() returns incomplete Node objects
* nodes(details=True) returns NodeDetail objects, which are exactly
  like complete Node objects, except that you cannot do anything
  with them: updating, listing VIFs, etc.
This is confusing and essentially requires the caller to issue
a redundant get_node call after listing detailed nodes.

This change consolidates everything into Node (Port, etc) objects
and deprecates NodeDetail (PortDetail, etc). I would highly recommend
the same approach taken for other ResourceDetail objects.

Change-Id: Idedee2b394e2ed412a69880d4bc9315737e1c3ed
'}]
commit_message:
Change approach to detailed listings of baremetal resources

The current approach with separate ResourceDetail classes suffers
from serious flows and is barely usable. For example for nodes:
* get_node() returns complete Node objects
* nodes() returns incomplete Node objects
* nodes(details=True) returns NodeDetail objects, which are exactly
  like complete Node objects, except that you cannot do anything
  with them: updating, listing VIFs, etc.
This is confusing and essentially requires the caller to issue
a redundant get_node call after listing detailed nodes.

This change consolidates everything into Node (Port, etc) objects
and deprecates NodeDetail (PortDetail, etc). I would highly recommend
the same approach taken for other ResourceDetail objects.

Change-Id: Idedee2b394e2ed412a69880d4bc9315737e1c3ed

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2018-11-09 04:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2018-11-15 08:09:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

I don't think this is a good plan...

If the usage count is incorrect (negative), we'll show 0.  The user will then create a resource, and maybe it still shows 0.  Then they create another, and the usage then shows 1.

This seems worse than just showing the incorrect value, because it hides a problem without really helping the situation.

If we show it, at least it's clear that the deployment needs some cleanup done."}, {'account_id': 28758, 'date': '2018-11-19 13:25:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

"If the usage count is incorrect (negative), we'll show 0. The user will then create a resource, and maybe it still shows 0. Then they create another, and the usage then shows 1."

When user creates another resource the request goes through quota_reserve() which is designed to handle negative in_use values: https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/4529b193da037c8b2bf09baf27fffc7856cb3241/cinder/db/sqlalchemy/api.py#L1268

When refresh is set quota_reserve() updates usage values based on real database content by calling the corresponding quota sync function. 

So when a "desync" happens (because quota mechanism keeps track of incremental updates to resources instead of computing the total on every upddate) causing the value to become negative this situation will last until the next quota_reserve() call.

Another argument for not returning negative values is that "usage" is by definition a value in range [0 ... max]'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2018-11-28 02:32:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Eric Do you have any comment about Daniel's idea?"}, {'account_id': 4523, 'date': '2018-11-28 15:41:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> When user creates another resource the request goes through quota_reserve() which is designed to handle negative in_use values

It is, but it shouldn't be.

> Another argument for not returning negative values is that "usage" is by definition a value in range [0 ... max]

Sure, no disagreement there.  But the problem is, we keep trying to add code to just paper over the problems here instead of actually fixing the quota system to actually work correctly.  I don't think that's a good strategy.'}]

   # Negative in_use count indicates a desync, so try to

commit_message:
limits show negative usage values

db/sqlalchemy/api.py quota_reserve() states that:

   # Negative in_use count indicates a desync, so try to
   # heal from that...

To avoid displaying negative values while this happens, so similar to
Horizon we're converting negative values to zero

Change-Id: Ic20c2f1f7d977518ab0ff9ddf14d3dcc44a51581
Co-authored-by: Daniel Badea <daniel.badea@windriver.com>
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>

(1 comment)

Thanks for looking into this.
The change however open the door to a backward incompatible change in the keystone API, which we should avoid.'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2017-07-17 07:50:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

The problem with original response it violates the law (rfc), which made previous contract (doc) invalid, since the rfc/law is stronger than an incompatible contract.

Tempest just started test to this call only in this cycle, in almost all RHEL7 family the response code was 200 in the prev years and nobody complained about it, I have doubts about is this change really causes an issue to any user.


It wouldn't be the first time, when we change an invalid response code by will. I would consider also back porting this change without worrying about micro versions as well.

You can have the newer mod_wsgi to behave similarly by 'WSGIMapHEADToGET On' , It has an automatic logic to turn it on/off so you might get it turned on implicitly in a more complex config."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2018-11-28 15:30:35.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Looks like there is not much interest for this change.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-06-30 12:30:32.000000000', 'message': 'keystone v3/roles head response code

The HTTP HEAD method expected to serve the
exact same headers and status code as GET would be,
just with empty response body.

However keystone gives you very different responses
on the /v3/roles/*/implies/* .

This change adds the 200 as an accepted status code
because it would be the correct one in the HTTP perspecive.

Some cases mod_wsgi itslef uses GET method instead
HEAD in order to enforce the proper headers which
leads to test failure.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I80eeaea8d23c81cb680b3d3888a95e6820169e20
Related-Bug: #1334368

commit_message:
keystone v3/roles head response code

The HTTP HEAD method expected to serve the
exact same headers and status code as GET would be,
just with empty response body.

However keystone gives you very different responses
on the /v3/roles/*/implies/* .

This change adds the 200 as an accepted status code
because it would be the correct one
 in the HTTP viewpoint.

Some cases mod_wsgi itself uses GET method instead
HEAD in order to enforce the proper headers which
leads to the test failure.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I80eeaea8d23c81cb680b3d3888a95e6820169e20
Related-Bug: #1701541

commit_message:
Ensure that a consistent mirror is used for RDO

This patch replicates the code added to openstack-ansible-tests into
the integrated repo. It obtains a URL for the RDO repo at the start
of a job which then has consistent contents for the duration of the job.

Change-Id: I6492c66ccc9d2b5b6de9ab6d08b377ac9e18e153

commit_message:
fixed alarm_url support ipv6

Now monitor the VNF. If the VNF address is IPV6,
it cannot use "http://ip:port",
should use "http://[ip]:port"

Change-Id: Ibf0d71468ebf65b1c900e01e0c6ce7a9cfffac2d

hmm, ssl related errors in gate-devstack-dsvm-updown ...'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2016-11-14 05:08:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

unfortunately I think something is going on with ssl certs here.  the suspicious warnings are in [1]

the updown test is a bit silly, in that it's testing cleanup so it goes ahead and deletes all the log files.  ergo it's hard to compare a failed instance to a working instance, because the working instance has no logs.

but, i think there's something going on with the ca bundle setup, maybe because the calls have moved.  in [2] you've got

  2016-11-14 01:14:09.998 | + lib/tls:fix_system_ca_bundle_path:368    :   capath=/etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt

and in [3] for comparison it is 

  2016-11-14 01:04:07.173 | + lib/tls:fix_system_ca_bundle_path:349    :   capath=/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/requests/cacert.pem

therefore, i think it might have something to do with ordering and pip install of pyopenssl or something?

why does this only affect the "updown"?  maybe because it's the only one leaving TLS defaults alone?

but yeah, i think there's a real problem lurking

commit_message:
nova: add support for TLS between novnc proxy & compute nodes

Nova is gaining the ability to run TLS over the connection between the
novnc proxy service and the QEMU/KVM compute node VNC server.

This adds a new config param - 'NOVA_CONSOLE_PROXY_COMPUTE_TLS=True' -
which instructs devstack to configure libvirt/QEMU to enable TLS for the
VNC server, and to configure the novncproxy to use TLS when connecting.
NB this use of TLS is distinct from use of TLS for the public facing API
controlled by USE_SSL, they can be enabled independently.

This is done in a generic manner so that it is easy to extend to cover
use of TLS with the SPICE and serial console proxy services too.

Change-Id: Ib29d3f5f18533115b9c51e27b373e92fc0a28d1a
Depends-on: I9cc9a380500715e60bd05aa5c29ee46bc6f8d6c2
Implements bp: websocket-proxy-to-host-security

commit_message:
Add devstack-tox-functional-no-ts job

This is a variant of the devstack-tox-functional job that doesn't
include the bindep and test-setup roles. The intention is that this can
be used to create integration jobs that run against multiple projects.

Change-Id: Ic6f27779e0e66e881576afd52a178a3555a4aed0

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
Make timeouts in functional tests configurable

functional tests are often failing due to timeouts in `wait_for`
functions. It forces us to trigger a "recheck". Let's make it
configurable instead. A top level timeout can be set
with `OPENSTACKSDK_FUNC_TEST_TIMEOUT` env and defaults to 300.
Func tests for each service might override this var
(i.e. for heat `OPENSTACKSDK_FUNC_TEST_TIMEOUT_ORCHESTRATE`).
OPENSTACKSDK_FUNC_TEST_TIMEOUT_LOAD_BALANCER is set to 600 (in tox)
to respect the value previously used in the code.

Change-Id: I7bdcd67e858a1f2c43cb131ebdf549da070fbb4a

commit_message:
fixed ping vim support ipv6

Now monitor the VIM. If the VIM address is IPV6,
it cannot use 'ping', should use ping6.

Change-Id: Ia731cacf0fdb54b2ea88379206d9d6811be62f1b

commit_message:
fixed ping vnf support ipv6

Now monitor the VNF. If the VNF address is IPV6,
it cannot use 'ping', should use ping6.

Change-Id: I7e7303bf1ee6c2e0c2995010564a93943aaacc49

"}, {'created': '2018-10-05 09:18:11.000000000', 'message': 'Use openstack/placement instead of placement-in-nova

We introduce and set PLACEMENT_REPO, add a placement-manage command
to create database tables (see one of the commits on which this
depends), use /etc/placement/placement.conf for config, and put the
uwsgi config file (pointing to placement-api instead of
nova-placement-api) in /etc/placement.

The depends-on are:

* a database table creation script (within placement)
* a grenade change to upgrade from placement-in-nova to placement
  migrating existing data

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/600161
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/604454
Change-Id: I0b217e7a8c68a637b7a3445f6c44b7574117e320
'}, {'created': '2018-10-08 15:49:25.000000000', 'message': 'Use openstack/placement instead of placement-in-nova

commit_message:
Use openstack/placement instead of placement-in-nova

We introduce and set PLACEMENT_REPO, add a placement-manage command
to sync database tables (see one of the commits on which this
depends), use /etc/placement/placement.conf for config, and put the
uwsgi config file (pointing to placement-api instead of
nova-placement-api) in /etc/placement.

openstack/placement is also added to the required-projects in
the devstack zuul job.

Change-Id: I0b217e7a8c68a637b7a3445f6c44b7574117e320

commit_message:
Add ceph-handler role

Ceph has introduces a ceph-handler role which includes all of the
handlers from now on, so we should include that from now on.

Change-Id: I9179a37eb4938eeaf09186144229af945eb350fa
(cherry picked from commit 0ac819c007dccfc5696015dea82186909a8182aa)

commit_message:
Fix UEFI firmware path and connection attribute in libvirt driver

Fixes libvirt domain XML build for UEFI boot and fixes typo in
connection attribute name in `set_boot_mode` method of the
libvirt driver.

Unit tests catching this bug reside in the next patch.

Change-Id: I63db95e83d42d59ea67d7fdfbbb1803ac7e5f9bb

commit_message:
rehome get_updatable_fields into object utils

This patch rehomes the get_updatable_fields function from
neutron.objects.base into neutron-lib. A unit test and release note
is also included.

Change-Id: I781607ca88626ac6e75b3df53ccee33f61c22fdf

commit_message:
Make ansible_host optional for all switch types

The Juniper device support allows ansible_host variable to not be set
for a switch, in which case the inventory_hostname will be used instead.

This change applies this default consistently across all switch types.

Change-Id: Ibc1e673a6b988f2e8d7bb6c62d30ccdb7ce96351
Story: 2004358
Task: 27958

commit_message:
Support for protecting nodes from undeploying and rebuilding

When handling the "pet" case, some nodes may be critical for the deployment.
For example, in an OpenStack installer like TripleO you may want to make
sure your controllers are not removed by an incorrect operation.

This changes introduces a new field "protected" on nodes. When it is
set to True, the "deleted" and "rebuild" provisioning actions fail with
HTTP 403.  Deleting such nodes is also not possible.

Also adds "protected_reason" for the operators to specify the reason
a node is protected.

Story: #2003869
Task: #26706
Change-Id: I1950bf6dd65b6596cae69d431ef288e578a89d6e

Add missing ws seperator between words

This is to add missing ws seperator between words, usually
in log messages.

[{'account_id': 29342, 'date': '2018-11-26 03:52:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-11-26 03:52:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 19644, 'date': '2018-11-26 13:36:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 29383, 'date': '2018-11-26 13:59:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 27181, 'date': '2018-11-26 18:16:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26222, 'date': '2018-11-28 05:36:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Add timeout to openstack command

There are cases when udercloud is not ready. This causes 'openstack' cli to
hang which is not good in case of ansible check. This patch adds timeout to
kill the process, then will cause ansible to retry the command again instead of
hang.

Change-Id: Ifaeff772a0c95ddb4d39c0a7b6fdd56a6abb023b
(cherry picked from commit 7e0412eb48e59036872d24544b5a61398eb740ce)

subject: Add check-errors flag to Introspection
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 10239, 'name': 'Dmitry Tantsur', 'email': 'dtantsur@protonmail.com', 'username': 'dtantsur'}, {'_account_id': 10343, 'name': 'Jim Rollenhagen', 'email': 'jim@jimrollenhagen.com', 'username': 'jimrollenhagen'}, {'_account_id': 15519, 'name': 'Iury Gregory Melo Ferreira', 'display_name': 'Iury Gregory', 'email': 'iurygregory@gmail.com', 'username': 'iurygregory'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23851, 'name': 'Riccardo Pittau', 'email': 'elfosardo@gmail.com', 'username': 'elfosardo'}, {'_account_id': 24828, 'name': 'Kaifeng Wang', 'email': 'kaifeng.w@gmail.com', 'username': 'wangkf'}, {'_account_id': 26340, 'name': 'Ilya Etingof', 'email': 'etingof@gmail.com', 'username': 'etingof'}]

[{'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2018-11-16 15:24:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2018-11-16 15:25:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Will create the task in storyboard and add a release note in next PS'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-11-16 16:53:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

Hey, thank you for the patch!

I have a couple of questions in-line.'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-11-19 03:18:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hello Iury, I am not quite sure I understand your purpose.

From code, it seems you introduced a new check if the quite is set, I agree with Ilya, you may need to elaborate your case to make it clear.

If the thing you need is something like verbose, you could reuse --debug option which is uniformly supported across all openstack projects I guess. You can LOG.debug on things you want to log whe --debug is specified.'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2018-11-19 12:59:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(4 comments)

Hello Ilya and Kaifeng, 

The problem we have is that if the introspection fails the exit status of the command is 0 if you check in terminal, the idea was add a quiet flag to handle the correct exit status code i add the information to the storyboard [1]


If an error occurs while using --quiet option in the introspection command we will be able to get exit status different from 0

[1] https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2004376'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2018-11-19 13:24:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-11-20 01:34:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

okay, I think I get some background on this patch.

This may need some discussion though, IMO the CLI should return 0 because the request is accepted, --wait just convert the async request to the sync one, if we want to check the result, I think it should be outside of the CLI. Is there any issue with scripting?

Besides, the "quiet" is quite confusing, and the help message didn't convey what the option is doing, I would prefer something like --report-error, --check-error, --ignore-error, or whatever but not quiet :)'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-11-20 01:41:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> --wait just convert the async request to the sync one,

I mean, --wait just make the async request behaving like a sync one from the caller side.'}, {'account_id': 26340, 'date': '2018-11-20 10:20:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I am second for revisiting the super confusing `--quiet` flag. May be something more explicit like `--return-error` would work better?

As I get it, returning error indication only makes sense in the sync mode. Should we may be make this implicit e.g. when `--wait` is given, exit code always indicates introspection outcome?'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2018-11-20 14:28:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hello Kaifeng and Ilya, 

I totally understand the point, are you guys ok with check-error for the flag? =)

@Kaifeng if we run the deployment in script at this point it should fail because there was an error in the introspection, but since the exit code is 0 it continues.'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2018-11-20 15:31:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-11-20 16:54:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 24828, 'date': '2018-11-21 03:10:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> if we run the deployment in script at this point it should
> fail because there was an error in the introspection, but since the
> exit code is 0 it continues.

We can check the introspection status once the introspection command (with wait) is returned, so I still think this is beyond the CLI, more like a check in the deployment script.'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2018-11-21 07:53:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15519, 'date': '2018-11-21 07:54:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2018-11-21 10:56:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+2

commit_message:
Add check-errors flag to Introspection

Failed introspection in OC returns 0, add check-errors
flag to handle if any errors occurred during the
introspection of nodes and get the correct exit status
code.

Change-Id: If30fdb9b8dbe29eb6803dafcde9380444e497e3d
Story: #2004376
Task: #27988

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I3ccc245b63a0586bd15c8546292651e5dff2e043
Closes-Bug:  #1801660

[{'created': '2018-10-26 22:47:06.000000000', 'message': 'Make access control annotations more generic.

This patch takes into consideration that there could be multiple
options for mandatory access control in a cluster. The previously
defined Helm toolkit function for generating a MAC annotation can
now be specified generically, like in this example:

  mandatory_access_control:
    mac_type: apparmor
    glance-api:
      init: runtime/default
      glance-api: runtime/default
      glance-perms: runtime/default
      ceph-keyring-placement: runtime/default
    glance-registry:
      init: runtime/default
      glance-registry: runtime/default

If no MAC is required, then the "mac_type" can be set to null,
and no annotation would be generated. The only MAC type supported
at the moment is "apparmor".

Change-Id: I6b45533d73af82e8fff353b0ed9f29f0891f24f1

commit_message:
Make access control annotations more generic.

This patch takes into consideration that there could be multiple
options for mandatory access control in a cluster. The previously
defined Helm toolkit function for generating a MAC annotation can
now be specified generically, like in this example:

  mandatory_access_control:
    type: apparmor
    glance-api:
      init: runtime/default
      glance-api: runtime/default
      glance-perms: runtime/default
      ceph-keyring-placement: runtime/default
    glance-registry:
      init: runtime/default
      glance-registry: runtime/default

If no MAC is required, then the "type" can be set to null,
and no annotation would be generated. The only MAC type supported
at the moment is "apparmor".

Change-Id: I6b45533d73af82e8fff353b0ed9f29f0891f24f1

3 remaining issues:

commit_message:
Update playbook to newer syntax.

---
[DEPRECATION WARNING]: Using tests as filters is deprecated.
Instead of using `result|success` use `result is success`.
This feature will be removed in version 2.9.
---

This patch updates the syntax to a non deprecated one

Change-Id: Ic3e549adb290b7024f5bb84f30a3a7cc3df97498

commit_message:
Remove "Change Password" from users table for non-admin users

If you're a user without administrative permissions, you will
not be able to edit a password using the table inside the identity
section due to the fact that it uses a different edit API which
is not meant to be used for the user-side of things.

This patch adds a policy change in order to hide the change password
link for normal users, while keeping the functionality inside
the Settings panel still intact.

This change was first broken by I76eb9f95c7112bcbad75ee151f363f892298d081

Partial-Bug: 1788384
Change-Id: I7a64257ac274c9dac5705ba72a85833f8e7a1591

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-16 11:54:12.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Do not overwrite password file during docker-puppet

When docker-puppet regenerates config during a stack update,
if a password changes in a config file, some services
(e.g. mysql) must change their internal state
(e.g. password in mysql DB) when paunch restarts them; and
they need the old password to achieve that.

For those services, update the config hash to notify
paunch that a restart is needed, but do not update the
password file in docker-puppet and let the service
regenerate it instead.

Change-Id: I5bdbc89897a6dcd5bd57f2132e2acf99702b28ea
Related-Bug: #1792416

commit_message:
mysql: do not overwrite password file during docker-puppet

During a stack update, when docker-puppet regenerates configs files for the
mysql service, the root mysql passwords may change. Mysql has to update its
internal state (e.g. password in mysql DB) to reflect the change, but this
only happens when paunch restarts mysql; and the old password it required
to until the change is applied.

For such services, update the config hash to notify paunch that a restart is
needed, but do not update the password file in docker-puppet and let the
service's containers regenerate it instead.

Change-Id: I5bdbc89897a6dcd5bd57f2132e2acf99702b28ea
Partial-Bug: #1792416

commit_message:
fixes how os-apply-config handles invalid json

If invalid json is included as the last element in
os_config_files.json it can silently break the file
customizations managed by os-apply-config.

More details:
https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1493303

Closes-Bug: #1722321

Change-Id: I0ad89fcde101ba6f3723ab2fa5a348c40452bae5
(cherry picked from commit f462d6fec8a4ae5c76a8f5e0d36e5dbb48917256)

commit_message:
Run online data migration before update/upgrade converge.

Some services have an online component to their upgrade
procedure ‚Äì operations which don‚Äôt induce downtime and
can run while the cloud operates normally.

Change-Id: I9b0bef15303bb14ef734b265f28607aa4d491910
(cherry picked from commit 43cc0dbec2ef91239f1800b8c693f121c3fb6c2d)

commit_message:
Fix new node detection

For the openshift-node service, the new_node detection was checking for
stdout instead of rc causing it to always tag nodes as new. This commit
fixes it.

Change-Id: I518f386395b515f59e98877274f4a0fce52ec4d5
Closes-Bug: #1802323
(cherry picked from commit 346929d9662e7168435cc524c8b9b4d8a68cf988)

[{'created': '2018-11-27 21:56:41.000000000', 'message': "Remove [keystone] config options from placement

Similar to I180a4df89d8338dc640dc2c5638775c65bde1cb7, this
removes the entire [keystone] group from placement.conf
since placement does not use it. The [keystone] group from
nova.conf was optionally used by a couple of compute APIs for
validating a user-provided project ID (flavor access and quota APIs).
Since placement doesn't use the options, they are removed here
so we don't have to go through a formal deprecation period.

While doing this, it was noticed that the [keystone_authtoken]
options, which *are* used by placement.auth.PlacementAuthProtocol
for the auth token middleware, were missing from the generated
placement config docs, so that's fixed in this change as well.

Change-Id: Ic856a4a43a21fbae3fe98466d1dc716d2736d622

commit_message:
Remove [keystone] config options from placement

Similar to I180a4df89d8338dc640dc2c5638775c65bde1cb7, this
removes the entire [keystone] group from placement.conf
since placement does not use it. The [keystone] group from
nova.conf was optionally used by a couple of compute APIs for
validating a user-provided project ID (flavor access and quota APIs).
Since placement doesn't use the options, they are removed here
so we don't have to go through a formal deprecation period after
placement is officially released. The placement/conf/utils.py
module is also not used so it is removed as well.

While doing this, it was noticed that the [keystone_authtoken]
options, which *are* used by placement.auth.PlacementAuthProtocol
for the auth token middleware, were missing from the generated
placement config docs, so that's fixed in this change as well.

Change-Id: Ic856a4a43a21fbae3fe98466d1dc716d2736d622

commit_message:
Fix HTTP response code on errors

Redfish requires returning HTTP codes in the range of 400-500
on failures. Such responses must be accompanied by error details
in form of a JSON document.

This patch makes general error handler returning HTTP code 500
instead of 200.

Change-Id: I89de76bc5e7d35f5130935af9f6ddd67e61d8b49

by default is network_interface

commit_message:
MNAIO: Add ability to deploy Ceph

This commit enables overriding the default storage options of
cinder/swift to a Ceph backed storage for the multinode all in one
deployments.

We also correct the README and build.sh script to show/use the
current defaults correctly for VM_DISK_SIZE and INFRA_VM_SERVER_RAM.

Change-Id: I9e1f1b09d1bcf224f4afa765c585baf28e6cafa8

messages: [{'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-18 17:21:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2018-10-18 21:00:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2018-11-27 07:55:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 7385, 'date': '2018-11-28 08:46:59.000000000', 'content': 'Created a revert of this change as Idb19dcd7e869085df7c740270d2fff8e4899fe5d'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-18 17:21:35.000000000', 'message': "Ensure Functions can be created without stack definition

In a number of places we parse templates passing None as the stack
definition, in order to be able to extract information from the template
in cases where we don't actually need to resolve functions.

However, the GetParam and GetFile HOT functions require an actual stack
definition to be passed in order to initialise them. So far we haven't
encountered any cases where those functions appear where we pass None
for the stack definition. Ensure that all Functions can always be
created even with no stack definition.

Note that the cfn ParamRef class is not affected, as the Ref function
always selects the GetResource implementation when the stack definition
is None.

Change-Id: Ic947dcdc17e9dbc58459a92ba970c292d70578cd
"}, {'created': '2018-10-18 21:00:34.000000000', 'message': "Ensure Functions can be created without stack definition

In a number of places we parse templates passing None as the stack
definition, in order to be able to extract information from the template
in cases where we don't actually need to resolve functions.

However, the GetParam and GetFile HOT functions require an actual stack
definition to be passed in order to initialise them. So far we haven't
encountered any cases where those functions appear where we pass None
for the stack definition. Ensure that all Functions can always be
created even with no stack definition.

Note that the cfn ParamRef class is not affected, as the Ref function
always selects the GetResource implementation when the stack definition
is None.

Change-Id: Ic947dcdc17e9dbc58459a92ba970c292d70578cd
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure Functions can be created without stack definition

In a number of places we parse templates passing None as the stack
definition, in order to be able to extract information from the template
in cases where we don't actually need to resolve functions.

However, the GetParam and GetFile HOT functions require an actual stack
definition to be passed in order to initialise them. So far we haven't
encountered any cases where those functions appear where we pass None
for the stack definition. Ensure that all Functions can always be
created even with no stack definition.

Note that the cfn ParamRef class is not affected, as the Ref function
always selects the GetResource implementation when the stack definition
is None.

Change-Id: Ic947dcdc17e9dbc58459a92ba970c292d70578cd

commit_message:
Test: cannot delete non-exist snapshot

This patch add test case: when assign non-exist snapshot-id
to delete snapshot, the program will raise SnapshotNotFound
error.

Change-Id: Id0637d0cfde2c60868002759036fa6f615a5ed0b

commit_message:
volume/rbd: Judge protected attr when deleting snapshot

When deleting rbd volume snapshot, it doesn't judge whether the
snapshot is protected before unprotect snapshot. This patch add
the judgment whether the snapshot is protected, only when snapshot
is protected, it can unprotect snapshot.

Change-Id: Iaa93985d78d7a3160fde6e9803bf10eae0da2a26

commit_message:
Add 'absent' service state

Allow deprecation of haproxy endpoints by setting the state of the
service to 'absent'. It will also now clean up any config files
when there are no backends, or the service is disabled.

Change-Id: I1db5932c559b5e04d330c114164869dd43c1cbb2
(cherry picked from commit 972ebbe5db3b5e340176640129b4dc7923ead8aa)

commit_message:
Wait for rpc server on shutdown

It seems to fix some busy epoll loop on SIGHUP.

Change-Id: I4f728d5b475fedce996baeaa526706235d781d9d
Related-Bug: #1795411

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-25 19:19:55.000000000', 'message': 'opt in for neutron-lib consumption patches

As part of the Denver PTG [1] we decided networking related projects
that are "current" and want to receive neutron-lib consumption patches
on an on-going basis should indicate such with a well defined comment
in their requirements.txt. This allows us to easily find the list of
project to receive neutron-lib consumption patches [2] by searching for
the string.

In addition, projects opting-in for these patches are also attesting
they will stay up to date with TC and infra initiatives to ensure
consumption patches can flow freely.

This patch adds the "neutron-lib-current" string to requirements.txt
opting in for neutron-lib consumption patches.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-stein-ptg
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron-lib/latest/contributor/contributing.html#phase-4-consume

Change-Id: Ibeb12dc75ff98e01f4b3b4c480e6a9d314c8b50a
'}]
commit_message:
opt in for neutron-lib consumption patches

As part of the Denver PTG [1] we decided networking related projects
that are "current" and want to receive neutron-lib consumption patches
on an on-going basis should indicate such with a well defined comment
in their requirements.txt. This allows us to easily find the list of
project to receive neutron-lib consumption patches [2] by searching for
the string.

In addition, projects opting-in for these patches are also attesting
they will stay up to date with TC and infra initiatives to ensure
consumption patches can flow freely.

This patch adds the "neutron-lib-current" string to requirements.txt
opting in for neutron-lib consumption patches.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron-stein-ptg
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/neutron-lib/latest/contributor/contributing.html#phase-4-consume

Change-Id: Ibeb12dc75ff98e01f4b3b4c480e6a9d314c8b50a

commit_message:
Support IPv6 address when validating interfaces

When processing introspection data from IPA, ironic inspector only accept IPv4
address of an interface. In a IPv6 environment, the port will not be collected
if processing.add_ports is not set to 'all'.

Story: #1744073
Task: #11374

Co-Authored-By: Kaifeng Wang <kaifeng.w@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0e1839df4d0e3b89f182ab98549486199d64c4ad

commit_message:
Capture ramdisk test run logs

I'm not sure why, but run_ramdisk_element_test is not using the same
interface as run_disk_element_test, despite being called the same way.
Update it so we are capturing logs.

Change-Id: I41b6a3f2d6e5466b340677c6252b7646c1dc2663

commit_message:
Don't set boot_option=local on baremetal flavors

Setting boot_option_local is no longer required as its the default.
So setting this is redundant.

Migrate existing flavors to remove boot_option if set to local.

Change-Id: Ib793acc98641091bcde2580b725656976e5d6625
Depends-On: I9fbe12f7878328f0ca084e29483f30d18dad1773
Related-Bug: #1803965

messages: [{'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-11-25 21:51:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21428, 'date': '2018-11-26 09:37:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 23365, 'date': '2018-11-27 05:17:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2018-11-28 03:06:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/rocky as commit 3adcd73ac7024ae084532d0d8fb264dad245b694'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-25 21:51:52.000000000', 'message': 'Set HTTP header "Origin" when using websocket

This is because if this header is missing, the websocket client
will populate this header as "http://...", which is incorrect
if we are using secure connection (in which this header should
be "https://...").

Change-Id: I441946dc168db645744da093e215f65fa1ca3637
Related-Bug: #1762511
'}]
commit_message:
Set HTTP header "Origin" when using websocket

This is because if this header is missing, the websocket client
will populate this header as "http://...", which is incorrect
if we are using secure connection (in which this header should
be "https://...").

Change-Id: I441946dc168db645744da093e215f65fa1ca3637
Related-Bug: #1762511

commit_message:
Allow wss as websocket protocol

Allow users to establish "wss" (secure web socket) connection to
the container. This is a client side fix but we also need to fix
the server to fully support "wss"

Change-Id: I1dd4f4872be03d1d80e3decbab18b41376230aba
Partial-Bug: #1762511

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-21 16:19:44.000000000', 'message': 'Remove keystoneauth1 opts from placement config group

The keystoneauth1 opts were included in the [placement] config group
in nova to define how nova was supposed to talk to the placement
service that it discovered in its service catalog.

Placement doesn't need to talk to itself, and for the time being it
doesn't need to talk to anyone else but the database, so we can
remove the settings. We do not need to deprecate them because we
have aleady declared that a "fresh config" is required and we
haven't had a release yet. If people have the settings in their
config files they simply won't be used.

Similar settings are registered in the [keystone] group, for

commit_message:
Remove keystoneauth1 opts from placement config group

The keystoneauth1 opts were included in the [placement] config group
in nova to define how nova was supposed to talk to the placement
service that it discovered in its service catalog.

Placement doesn't need to talk to itself, and for the time being it
doesn't need to talk to anyone else but the database, so we can
remove the settings. We do not need to deprecate them because we
have already declared that a "fresh config" is required and we
haven't had a release yet. If people have the settings in their
config files they simply won't be used.

Similar settings are registered in the [keystone] group which
will be cleaned up in a separate change (note that the [keystone]
group is not the same as the [keystone_authtoken] group which
is used by the authtoken API middleware).

There's no test coverage for these because any tests which would
have used them are still in nova. Integration tests will make
sure this change is fine.

Change-Id: I180a4df89d8338dc640dc2c5638775c65bde1cb7

1. Added UT
2. Removed [WIP], and it's ready for core's review"}, {'account_id': 28758, 'date': '2018-11-20 08:08:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2018-11-20 10:07:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2018-11-21 12:49:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2

Here's why I don't like this patch:

(1) It is not a good idea to introduce new functionality based on a deprecated configuration option.

(2) There is an existing workaround for this, namely to have a dedicated glance node for nova with a different configuration and policy file than public-facing glance nodes.

(3) The proper way to fix this is going to be refactoring the locations policies code (and possibly rethinking the locations policies).  There's a draft spec for this:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/528021/2
Unfortunately, no one has been able to commit time to working on this issue."}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2018-11-28 01:53:12.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Thanks for the comments from Rosmaita. 1. Abandon here.
2. Mark as "Maintain" internally
3. Pay attention to rosmaita's comment(3), try to help here if time planned'}]

commit_message:
Allow adding location when no location exists

Allow adding location for images but only if there is no previous
location set. e.g. This enables nova snapshot support for
boot-from-image rbd backed instances.

Related review that added the check of CONF.show_multiple_locations
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/280786

Change-Id: I9feed7f51a592fa88bb91f330d75df1468d7c467
Co-authored-by: Daniel Badea <daniel.badea@windriver.com>
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Add description field to image information

Like nova, cinder, adding the ``description`` field to the image can
better mark the purpose of the image. For users, this is very friendly
in environments with lots of images.

APIImpact

Blueprint: add-description-field-to-image

Change-Id: I3d9d043e9dc5364eae5aa758c8b8f7e8708efbdb

commit_message:
doc: Change variable name DEFAULT_API_VERSION to _MIN_API_VERSION

The DEFAULT_API_VERSION variable doesn't exist in the specified
file.
As stated in [1], _MIN_API_VERSION is used as the default api
version if no version is specified.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/api/openstack/api_version_request.py#L133-L136

Change-Id: I6ecd0b2993c00c3abea98afc5be63bc8dc78624e

commit_message:
Include all rootwrap filters when building wheels

The current method of specifying each rootwrap filter
in the file list is prone to errors when adding or
removing filters. Instead of relying on a manually
maintained list this patch just includes all the files
of the correct naming convention from the applicable
folder. This is simpler and easier to maintain.

Closes-Bug: #1718356
Change-Id: I7f8c55f63d1c5a85a6a92062e918426f7d2d3c35
(cherry picked from commit 45f1404c68553fd01f386522dd16841526c68dbf)

commit_message:
Include all rootwrap filters when building wheels

The current method of specifying each rootwrap filter
in the file list is prone to errors when adding or
removing filters. Instead of relying on a manually
maintained list this patch just includes all the files
of the correct naming convention from the applicable
folder. This is simpler and easier to maintain.

Closes-Bug: #1718356

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0. Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I005b46aebeb7f347b6721790723ea6be41a0d67e

commit_message:
New plugin to check for ignoring host keys

This new plugin adds a check that detects whether some code using
paramiko is ignoring the host key verification.  Ignoring a host
key is the equivalent of ignoring a certificate as part of the
TLS protocol.

Change-Id: Ib6991105c6efd7b8139cd7021b03d0188e4c9133

messages:
[{'account_id': 27736, 'date': '2018-02-06 19:29:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-02-06 19:29:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
Improve deteccion for mark_safe
- Add introspection to detect static strings in order to minimize the false positives.

Change-Id: I4f2d8d5262e89cf6017d946bf1efa5966ad6be95

(2 comments)

So this check only cares about Python 2. You'll also need to check `six.moves.builtins` and the `builtins` module in Python 3 [1]. On top of all of that, you can also replace True and False (your example) without using `__builtins__`. So perhaps you should also do something like:

    from six.moves import builtins


    # In the check function
    SENTINEL = object()
    if getattr(builtins, target.name, SENTINEL) is not SENTINEL:  # It is a builtin
       return bandit.Issue

(In case it isn't obvious, I don't think we should only be checking for tuples.)

[1]: https://docs.python.org/3/library/builtins.html"}, {'account_id': 11716, 'date': '2016-09-20 12:56:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Workflow-1

Nice suggestions, thanks Ian :) I'll look at what you have described."}, {'account_id': 11716, 'date': '2016-09-20 13:00:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

the tuple is actually down to the logic of the test, not the thing we are testing for so

__builtins__.False, __builtins__.int = float will trip it, however this is clearly wrong, so mea culpa, will update it :)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-09-20 16:31:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified-1

@Ian thanks for thin previous suggestion, in the end I didn't use 'if getattr(builtins, target.name, SENTINEL)' etc because shadowing a builtin i.e. 'True = False' did not produce the same effect as replacing it in builtins. You can prove this by shadowing the builtin in the local module scope and then importing a second module. The second module will have the correct value for True. If replaced in builtins then all modules (that did not shadow anything) will now see the new value of True."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-10 11:14:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

commit_message:
Create certificates are package installs

When setting certificate folders to /etc/octavia/certs
or similar that depends on /etc/octavia folder the resource
will fail because it doesn't create the whole folder path
recursively.

This changes the dependency chaining to make sure that
certificates are modified after package installs so that
the /etc/octavia folder for example is available.

Closes-Bug: 1804883
Change-Id: I551053b96fde110478945955f3d7dc42bf3e65ef

commit_message:
Set show_diff to false on certificates

Certificate should be considered secrets
and we should not output the diffs.

Also fixes up the testing to test all the
parameters set on the file resources.

Closes-Bug: 1804884
Change-Id: I0db84f4b9d97bf22d06478ded126a1f209c9b69a

commit_message:
Add py36 tox environment

We already run python3.6 unit tests in CI. Add the py36 environment to
the tox file so that developers with python3.6 available locally can opt
into running that version too.

Change-Id: Ic7aad3d4adfafba226d3b1d1b2106d55135ce6ff

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-29 21:22:46.000000000', 'message': "Allow re-execution in testing

Presently virtualbmc returns an error indicating
that the instance is already running when the user
attempts to remove it from virtualbmc.

Due to the workflow virtualbmc requires, you can't delete
after a VM instance has been destroyed, so it becomes a
slight chicken and egg problem. This will at least allow
re-execution for users testing with virtual machines.

Change-Id: I5cd70ceea2ce4e037526db054137e62f0bae3655
"}]
commit_message:
Allow re-execution in testing

Presently virtualbmc returns an error indicating
that the instance is already running when the user
attempts to remove it from virtualbmc.

Due to the workflow virtualbmc requires, you can't delete
after a VM instance has been destroyed, so it becomes a
slight chicken and egg problem. This will at least allow
re-execution for users testing with virtual machines.

Change-Id: I5cd70ceea2ce4e037526db054137e62f0bae3655

commit_message:
Improve logs when hard linking images fails

When hard linking images fail in ironic the logs doesn't have
enough related path information to resolve the underlying cause
of the exception.

Change-Id: I3331c4eca2deb9383f448f1efa93cbef53019f9c
Story: #2004303
Task: #27863
(cherry picked from commit 46a5899543bce73e1d40f6f363031f9ac1a472e8)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-27 18:43:26.000000000', 'message': 'Stop using deprecated rpc_backend option

oslo.messaging deprecated the rpc_backend option long ago, but it was
still being used in cinder unit test configuration fixtures. oslo.messaging
9.0.0 finally removed that option, so now the tests are failing.

This change replaces use of rpc_backend with the corresponding
transport_url option that as recommended at:

https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.messaging/latest/configuration/conffixture.html

It also removes a redundant setUp() override.

Change-Id: I7cc823e96da1fd38ba28650b72a358e792d7c892
Closes-Bug: #1796759
(cherry picked from commit 978f02d2194f879c6a2f1f1e4b3efefc6464526c)
'}]
commit_message:
Stop using deprecated rpc_backend option

oslo.messaging deprecated the rpc_backend option long ago, but it was
still being used in cinder unit test configuration fixtures. oslo.messaging
9.0.0 finally removed that option, so now the tests are failing.

This change replaces use of rpc_backend with the corresponding
transport_url option that as recommended at:

https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.messaging/latest/configuration/conffixture.html

It also removes a redundant setUp() override.

Change-Id: I7cc823e96da1fd38ba28650b72a358e792d7c892
Closes-Bug: #1796759
(cherry picked from commit 978f02d2194f879c6a2f1f1e4b3efefc6464526c)

commit_message:
DNM install tar-split

This is a Go based utility not yet in RDO dependencies but required
for the python based container image uploader.

The source is already vendored into podman, skopeo and buildah, and
the tar-split utility allows it to be used in non-go scenarios.

https://github.com/vbatts/tar-split

Change-Id: I2e74a9e8930e6965ac271e2770fc53889775688b

commit_message:
Deprecate pki related options

check_revocations_for_cached and hash_algorithms are deprecated for
removel because of PKI token format is no longer supported.
Update warning message and add a release note.

Change-Id: I0ad17b24278372f9f3648450f23957413a1f40d3
Closes-Bug: #1804562
Closes-Bug: #1804720

subject: Bump sqlalchemy minimum version to 1.1.0
messages:
[{'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-10-29 03:18:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-11-12 02:52:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-11-12 03:10:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-11-12 06:54:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27621, 'date': '2018-11-13 02:43:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11022, 'date': '2018-11-13 05:59:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

can you explain how this feature enables the possibility of having long passwords? I couldn't make an association based only in the official doc."}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2018-11-13 08:05:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> can you explain how this feature enables the possibility of having
 > long passwords? I couldn't make an association based only in the
 > official doc.

When set/update password, keystone will convert the input dict to sql model first[1]. Then it will check if the input is follow the model's limit or not[2]. Unfortunately, "password"'s length limit is 128[3]. So if the input is longer than 128, the error StringLengthExceeded will be raised.

Then in Sqlalchemy v1.1.0, hybrid property has it own Class Name(not InstrumentedAttribute). `"password" is a hybrid property in User model[4]. So in this case, it'll skip the length check.

Then the behavior is what we want for "password".

[1]:https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/identity/backends/sql.py#L129
[2]:https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/common/sql/core.py#L103-L110
[3]:https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py#L300
[4]:https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/identity/backends/sql_model.py#L104'}, {'account_id': 11022, 'date': '2018-11-13 22:36:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

thank you!'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-11-26 22:18:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2018-11-26 23:09:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-11-27 19:54:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

My questions were answered and I think we can address my nit in a follow-up.

Thanks for figuring out how to recreate this with the sqla versions.'}]

commit_message:
Bump sqlalchemy minimum version to 1.1.0

Sqlalchemy add a new class for hybrid property in v1.1.0[1]. It
can solve the password length problem for User password SQL obj.

[1]: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/changelog/migration_11.html#change-3653

Change-Id: I7a18bd528607ec5112cc55c7682f95d61be8b509
Closes-bug: #1735250

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-11-26 16:29:15.000000000', 'message': "Update hook to remove old ceph.conf alternatives

When adding ceph-mon relation to cinder, the charm installs ceph.conf
with the update-alternatives via cinder_utils.resource_map().
However when the relation is removed, the alternative isn't cleaned up.
This can cause issues if installing a cinder-ceph subordinate charm.
The cinder-ceph charm also installs a ceph.conf alternative that will
point to the leftover ceph.conf installed by the ceph-mon charm.

Added remove_alternative() in ceph-relation-broken hook to ensure
that leftover ceph.conf alternatives is removed upon relation removal.

Change-Id: I308e62a626f31eb8ef690a09035fe3908920ccc9
Closes-Bug: 1778084
"}, {'created': '2018-11-26 19:04:42.000000000', 'message': "Update hook to remove old ceph.conf alternatives

When adding ceph-mon relation to cinder, the charm installs ceph.conf
with the update-alternatives via cinder_utils.resource_map().
However when the relation is removed, the alternative isn't cleaned up.
This can cause issues if installing a cinder-ceph subordinate charm.
The cinder-ceph charm also installs a ceph.conf alternative that will
point to the leftover ceph.conf installed by the ceph-mon charm.

Added remove_alternative() in ceph-relation-broken hook to ensure
that leftover ceph.conf alternatives is removed upon relation removal.

Change-Id: I308e62a626f31eb8ef690a09035fe3908920ccc9
Closes-Bug: 1778084
"}]
commit_message:
Update hook to remove old ceph.conf alternatives

When adding ceph-mon relation to cinder, the charm installs ceph.conf
with the update-alternatives via cinder_utils.resource_map().
However when the relation is removed, the alternative isn't cleaned up.
This can cause issues if installing a cinder-ceph subordinate charm.
The cinder-ceph charm also installs a ceph.conf alternative that will
point to the leftover ceph.conf installed by the ceph-mon charm.

Added remove_alternative() in ceph-relation-broken hook to ensure
that leftover ceph.conf alternatives is removed upon relation removal.

Change-Id: I308e62a626f31eb8ef690a09035fe3908920ccc9
Closes-Bug: 1778084

commit_message:
Add integrated-gate-py35 template to .zuul.yaml

This adds full tempest and grenade runs to placement changes
to ensure placement doesn't break the world. This runs just
py3 jobs to avoid duplication.

The Depends-On are to

* the devstack change which provides an extracted placement.
  That change depends on the necessary database and CLI
  changes in placement itself.
* addition of grenade-py35 job to the template
* fix to grenade for openstack client + swift under python3

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/600162
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/617662
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/619728
Change-Id: I5ac7c1cdffe2956d3091a6052058068ee1b067da
